revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox NRHP|nocat=1 | name = Lincoln Park Lily Pool | nrhp_type = nhld | designated_other1_name = Chicago Landmark | designated_other1_abbr = CL | designated_other1_color = #aaccff | designated_other1_link = Chicago Landmark | designated_other1_date = November 6, 2002 | image =Alfred Caldwell Lily Pond with rocks.jpg | caption = | location = Fullerton Parkway between Cannon and Stockton Drives in Lincoln Park, [[Chicago, IL]] | area = {{convert|3|acre|ha}} | architect = [[Alfred Caldwell]] | architecture = | added = February 17, 2006 | designated_nrhp_type = February 17, 2006 | governing_body = Local | refnum=06000235<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2007a}}</ref> | nrhp_type2 = cp | designated_nrhp_type2 = August 26, 1994 | partof = [[Lincoln Park]] | partof_refnum = 94001029 }} The '''Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool''', also known as '''[[Lincoln Park]] Lily Pool''', is an important example of [[Prairie School]] [[landscape architecture]] designed by [[Alfred Caldwell]] and located at 125 W. Fullerton Parkway (between Stockton and Cannon Drives) in [[Lincoln Park, Chicago|Lincoln Park]], [[Chicago, Illinois]]. Developed in 1936-38, it is one of Caldwell's most fully realized designs.<ref name="NRHP Registration"/> It was designated a [[Chicago Landmark]] on November 6, 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://webapps.cityofchicago.org/LandmarksWeb/landmarkDetail.do?lanID=1261 |title=Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool |publisher=City of Chicago Department of Planning and Development, Landmarks Division |year=2003 |accessdate=June 16, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080613043941/http://webapps.cityofchicago.org/LandmarksWeb/landmarkDetail.do?lanID=1261 |archivedate=June 13, 2008 }}</ref> It was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] and as a [[National Historic Landmark]] on February 17, 2006.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=-684823132&ResourceType=District |title=Lincoln Park Lily Pool |publisher=National Park Service |accessdate=May 10, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103060222/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=-684823132&ResourceType=District |archivedate=January 3, 2008 }}</ref>
==History== A Victorian-style artificially heated lily pool had originally been built in 1889 at the behest of Lincoln Park Commission Superintendent John Pettigrew to cultivate tropical [[Nymphaeaceae|water lilies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagoparkdistrict.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/custom.natureOasis06|archive-url=https://archive.is/20070505143718/http://www.chicagoparkdistrict.com/index.cfm/fuseaction/custom.natureOasis06|dead-url=yes|archive-date=May 5, 2007|accessdate=May 10, 2007|year=2006|publisher=Chicago Park District|title=Lincoln Park Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool}}</ref><ref name="NRHP Registration">{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=06000235}}|title=National Historic Landmark Nomination: Lincoln Park Lily Pool |publisher=[[National Park Service]]|author=Julia Sniderman Bachrach, Patty Henry, and Carolyn Pitts |date=December 2004 |accessdate=April 20, 2017 }} With {{NRHP url|id=06000235|photos=y|title=12 photos}}.</ref>
The lilies proved hard to cultivate and maintain in the northern climate of Illinois and the pools became unsightly and were often considered "Pettigrew's frog ponds".<ref>{{cite book|title= Prairie in the City: Naturalism in Chicago's Parks, 1870-1940|editor-first=Rosemary|editor-last=Adams|editor2-first=Claudia|editor2-last=Lamm Wood|last1=Sniderman|first1=Julia|chapter=Bringing the Prairie Vision into Focus|publisher=Chicago Historical Society|page=129|date=1991}}</ref> By the 1930s the hour-glass shaped pond and its environs had fallen into ruin and disrepair. Landscape architect [[Alfred Caldwell]] was hired by the [[Works Progress Administration]] to completely redesign this area of Lincoln Park.<ref name="NRHP Registration"/><ref>Mark Rosenthal, et al., Ark in the Park (University of Illinois, 2003) p. 66.</ref> Caldwell realized that the Lily Pool presented him with the unique opportunity to realize his poetic symbolism and design theories and philosophies.<ref name=Plan />
In 1938 the project was nearing completion and the park district decide to cut a major expenditure for wildflower plantings. Caldwell cashed in his $5000 life insurance policy for $250, bought thousands of plants and transported them from Sauk County, Wisconsin, and the next day planted them all around the lily pools with the help of four others.<ref name= Maloney /><ref name=Garden>{{cite web|last1=Grano|first1=Laurie|title=The Alfed Caldwell Lily Pool at Lincoln Park|url=http://www.gardendesign.com/visit/lily-pool-revival-the-alfred-caldwell-lily-pool-at-chicagos-lincoln-park|website=gardendesign.com|publisher=Garden Design Magazine|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}</ref> The pool area is located just north of [[Lincoln Park Zoo]] and next to the [[Lincoln Park Conservatory]].
===Features=== [[File:20100801 Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool from southsoutheast-2 cropped.jpg|thumb|Pool in 2010]] Caldwell had worked for landscape artist [[Jens Jensen (landscape architect)|Jens Jensen]] from 1926 to 1931. Jensen's influence on Caldwell and the Lily Pool is evident in the Sun Opening or clearing, the curving walkways and meandering, stepping-stone limestone paths, and the circular benches that Jensen referred to as "the council ring" and "friendship circles" since there was no superior position to sit in. [[Frank Lloyd Wright]]'s influence is represented in the organic architecture of the shelter and the Fullerton Parkway Gate, a prairie-style entryway into the property.<ref name=Plan />
===The Rookery === In the early 1950s, under Zoo Director [[Marlin Perkins]], the pool was transformed into a water exhibit featuring exotic birds and water fowl and came to be known as The Rookery. Overgrazing by zoo birds had a devastating effect on the [[Garden pond|lily pond]]. A lack of landscaping management allowing invasive plants and "weed" trees to take over the understory, heavy human foot traffic, uncontrolled erosion, the introduction of plants materials that were invasive to the existing lilies, and inappropriate repairs (eroded areas covered with [[Rip-rap|loose stones]]) all resulted in what Caldwell called (in 1990) "a dead world".<ref name=Maloney>{{cite book|last1=Maloney|first1=Cathy Jean|title=Chicago Gardens:The Earliest History|date=2008|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, Illinois|isbn=9780-226-502-342|pages=464|edition=first}}</ref><ref name=oasis>{{cite web|title=Neglected Oasis to gain New Life When Zoo's Rookery is Renovated|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2000-05-11/news/0005110168_1_park-district-parking-lot-frank-lloyd-wright|website=chicagotribune.com|publisher=The Chicago Tribune|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}</ref>
===Renovation=== From 1998 to 2002, the 2.7 acre Lily Pool underwent a major restoration by the [[Chicago Park District]] and the Lincoln Park Conservancy. The Friends of Lincoln Park (now called The Lincoln Park Conservancy) raised $1.2 million toward the restoration of the lily pools. A similar sum was obtained from a grant from the [[United States Forest Service|USDA Forest Service]]. Wolff Landscape Architecture was hired to complete the project.
Five focus groups were conducted to develop a consensus plan for restoration of the site;<ref name=Plan>{{cite journal|title=Concept Plan for the Rehabilitation of the Lily Pool|journal=The Lily Pool|publisher=Friends of Lincoln Park|location=Chicago, IL}}</ref> #experts in historic preservation, #bird watchers and ecologists, #Individuals knowledgeable about Lincoln Park and active in its planning and management, #activists and experts on the subject of accessibility, #members of the general public.
The Chicago Park District and the Lincoln Park Conservancy manage a docent program at the Caldwell Lily Pool.<ref name= CPD>{{cite web|title=Alfred Caldwell Lily pool Docent Training|url=http://www.chicagoparkdistrict.com/jobs-volunteering/alfred-caldwell-lily-pool-docent-training/|website=chicagoparkdistrict.com|publisher=Chicago Park District|accessdate=May 5, 2015}}</ref>
==Location== The Lily Pool's main gate is on the south side of Fullerton Parkway between Stockton and Cannon Drives (125 W Fullerton Parkway).<ref name=Maloney />
The Lily Pool is open seasonally from mid-April to mid-November from 7:30 a.m. to the earlier of dusk or 7:30 p.m. It is maintained by the Chicago Park District and Lincoln Park Conservancy.<ref name= CPD />
Free docent tours are available to the public on Fridays, Saturdays or Sundays from the Spring through Fall.<ref name= CPD />
<gallery mode=packed heights=180> 20070516 Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool.jpg| May 2007 Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool Fall 2010.JPG|October 2010 Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool October.JPG|Pool in Fall 2010 </gallery>
==See also== {{Portal|Chicago}} {{commonscat|Alfred Caldwell Lily Pool}} * [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Chicago]] * [[List of National Historic Landmarks in Illinois]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{coord|41.9253|-87.6341|type:landmark_region:US-IL|display=title}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Beacon-diabases.jpg|thumb|400px|The Beacon Supergroup and diabase intrusions.]] [[File:Taylorglacier pho 2013 studinger.jpg|thumb|400px|Beacon Supergroup in [[Taylor Valley]]. The tan bands are Beacon Sandstone layers, and the dark layers are [[diabase]] sills, intruded about 180 million years ago.]] The '''Beacon Supergroup''' is a geological formation exposed in Antarctica and deposited from the [[Devonian]] to the [[Triassic]] ({{Ma|400|250}}). The unit was originally described as either a formation or sandstone, and upgraded to group and supergroup as time passed. It contains a sandy member known as the Beacon heights orthoquartzite. <ref>[http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/381/1/67 Bradshaw, M. (2013, August 6) The Taylor Group (Beacon Supergroup): the Devonian sediments of Antarctica], Geological Society (81), 67-97. Accessed December 13, 2013.</ref>
==Setting in time and space== Named after [[Beacon Heights]].<ref name=GPDF>{{cite journal | first =Duncan, Jr. | last = Stewart | title = The Petrography of the Beacon Sandstone of the South Victoria Land | url = http://www.minsocam.org/ammin/AM19/AM19_351.pdf |format=PDF| journal = Mineralogical Society of America | accessdate = 2008-04-23 }}</ref> First named 1907, type section described in 1963.<ref name=Hamilton1963>{{cite journal|vauthors=Hamilton W, Hayes PT|lastauthoramp=yes |title=Type section of the Beacon Sandstone of Antarctica|url=https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/usgspubs/pp/pp456A|year=1963|journal=US Geol Survey Prof paper|volume=456-A|pages=1–18}}</ref> Originally dubbed a formation, with scope left (and later used) to expand to group, then supergroup, as better mapped and understood.<ref name=Hamilton1963/> [[Beacon Dome]] at the head of [[Griffith Glacier]] is named after the Beacon Supergroup.
===Age=== *Upper Devonian to Triassic
===Exposure=== * Antarctica: McMurdo sound, shores of [[Ross Bay]];<ref name=NHM>{{cite web |title=Scott's Terra Nova Antarctic Expedition |url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/research-curation/collections/departmental-collections/mineralogy-collections/rocks/scott-collection.html |accessdate=2008-04-23 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080320090044/http://www.nhm.ac.uk/research-curation/collections/departmental-collections/mineralogy-collections/rocks/scott-collection.html |archivedate=2008-03-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> also southern [[Victoria Land]], [[Ross desert]].<ref name=Friedmann1987>{{cite journal | author = Friedmann, E.I. |author2= Weed, R. | year = 1987 | title = Microbial trace-fossil formation, biogenous, and abiotic weathering in the Antarctic cold desert | journal = Science | volume = 236 | issue = 4802 | pages = 703–705 | doi = 10.1126/science.11536571 | pmid = 11536571 }}</ref> * Described by Scott & team on way to South Pole.<ref name=Elliott1963>{{cite journal | author = Elliott, R.B. |author2= Evans, W.D. | year = 1963 | title = A Beacon Sandstone: its Petrology and Hydrocarbon Content | journal = Nature | volume = 199 | issue = 4894 | pages = 686–687 | doi = 10.1038/199686b0 |bibcode = 1963Natur.199..686E }}</ref>
The series is over 1 km thick in places,<ref name=Elliott1963/> and extends for over 1,000 miles.<ref name=Elliott1963/>
The beds are almost flat lying,<ref name=Elliott1963/> dipping at about 3° to the north;<ref name=Kamp1982>{{cite journal | author1 = Kamp, P.J.J. | author2= Lowe, D.J. | year = 1982 | title = Geology and terrestrial age of the Derrick Peak meteorite occurrence, Antarctica | journal = Meteoritics | volume = 17 | pages = 119–127 | bibcode = 1982Metic..17..119K | doi=10.1111/j.1945-5100.1982.tb00563.x }}</ref> many are interleaved with dolerite sills.<ref name=Elliott1963/>
===Location=== The location of the formation in a cold, desert environment, and the lack of nutrients or soil (due to the purity of the sandstone) has led to the beacon sandstone being considered the closest analogue on Earth to Martian conditions, therefore many studies have been performed on life's survival there, mainly focusing on the [[lichen]] communities that form the modern inhabitants.<ref name=Using2008>e.g. {{cite journal |author1=Derek Pullan |author2=Frances Westall |author3=Beda A. Hofmann |author4=John Parnell |author5=Charles S. Cockell |author6=Howell G.M. Edwards |author7=Susana E. Jorge Villar |author8=Christian Schroder |author9=Gordon Cressey |author10=Lucia Marinangeli |author11=Lutz Richter |author12=Gostar Klingelhofer. | year = 2008 | title = Identification of Morphological Biosignatures in Martian Analogue Field Specimens Using ''In Situ''v Planetary Instrumentation | journal = Astrobiology | volume = 8 | issue = 1 | doi = 10.1089/ast.2006.0037 | pages = 119–56 | pmid = 18211229 | bibcode=2008AsBio...8..119P }}</ref>
==Sedimentology== [[Image:Beacon-crossbedding.jpg|thumb|Cross-bedding in sandstone of the Beacon Supergroup suggests a fluvial environment.]] The unit is a "Fine grained, [[arkose|arkosic]] quartz sandstone".<ref name=Angino1962/> It is composed of [[shale]]s, coals, [[Conglomerate (geology)|conglomerates]], and in places the occasional thin limestone bed.<ref name=Angino1962/>
===Lithofacies=== Originally divided into 3 subunits,<ref name=Elliott1963/> further refined into five facies, listed below from oldest to youngest:<ref name=Gevers1971/>
====Brown hills conglomerate==== Basal. Grades into Junction sandstone. Variable thickness; (0-5<ref name=Hamilton1963/>/17<ref name=Bradshaw2007/>/80<ref name=Woolfe1993>{{cite journal | author = Woolfe, K.J. | year = 1993 | title = Devonian depositional environments in the Darwin Mountains: Marine or non-marine? | journal = Antarctic Science | volume = 5 | issue = 2 | pages = 211–220 | doi = 10.1017/S0954102093000276 | bibcode = 1993AntSc...5..211W }}</ref> m),<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> overlies pre-Devonian plutonic rocks, of igneous and metamorphic nature, with over 30 m erosional relief.<ref name=Hamilton1963/> Contains igneous and metamorphic clasts.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/>
Poorly sorted at base, influxes of coarser material.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Coarseness is laterally variable - pebbles in places, sands in others, at same horizons.<ref name=Woolfe1993/> Planar beds, trough cross-bedding, [[flaser bed]]ding, mud-drapes on some ripples; U-shaped burrows & escape structures; fining up cycles topped by desiccation cracks in places.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/><ref name=Woolfe1993/>
Probably alluvial fan. Unidirectional flow & sheet-like deposition point to braided channels.<ref name=Woolfe1993/>
====Junction sandstone==== Part of Taylor group.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Gradational boundaries at top and bottom.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> up to 540m thick.<ref name=Woolfe1993/> ''[[Skolithos]]'' abundant.<ref name=Woolfe1993/> Intermediate between Brown Hills Conglomerate and Hatherton sandstone.
====Hatherton sandstone==== Part of Taylor group.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> 250-300m thick.<ref name=Woolfe1993/> Divided into upper and lower subunits.<ref name=Gevers1971/> * 95% Quartz.<ref name=Angino1962/> * Abundant: Zircon, limonite. Common: garnet, magnetite. Present in places: Shell fragments (Brachiopod / bivalve)<ref name=Angino1962>{{cite journal | author = Angino, E.E. |author2= Owen, D.E. | year = 1962 | title = Sedimentologic Study of Two Members of the Beacon Formation, Windy Gully, Victoria Land, Antarctica | journal = Transactions of the Kansas Academy of Science (1903-) | volume = 65 | issue = 1 | pages = 61–69 | doi = 10.2307/3626470 | publisher = Transactions of the Kansas Academy of Science (1903-), Vol. 65, No. 1 | jstor = 3626470 }}</ref>
Lower: white/yellow sandstone.<ref name=Gevers1971/> Layers of grit/conglomerate at base, silt at top, of some beds, which reach 15m thickness.<ref name=Gevers1971/> Trough cross beds.<ref name=Woolfe1994/>
Upper: Similar, but rust-weathering, current rippling.<ref name=Gevers1971/>
Dates to late Middle Devonian, by correlation to the well constrained (by fish fossils) Aztec Siltstone nearby.<ref name=Woolfe1994>{{cite journal | author = Woolfe, K.J. | year = 1994 | title = Cycles of erosion and deposition during the Permo-Carboniferous glaciation in the Transantarctic Mountains | journal = Antarctic Science | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 93–104 | doi = 10.1017/S095410209400012X | bibcode = 1994AntSc...6...93W }}</ref>
Abundant [[ichnology|ichnofauna]].<ref name=Gevers1971/>
Common bedforms: planar beds, bi-modal cross-beds, [[hummocky cross-stratification]] (HCS), laminated seds.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Drainage to north east.<ref name=Woolfe1993/>
Presumed marine for a long time on the basis of trace fossils such as ''[[Skolithos]]'', and typically marine HCS. But sedimentologists kept pointing out subaerial features such as desiccation cracks (polygonal jointing?), rain drop impressions, surface run-off channels, muddy veneers, and redbeds; also, river-like features such as unidirectional currents and small channels.<ref name=Woolfe1990>{{cite journal | author = Woolfe, K.J. | year = 1990 | title = Trace fossils as paleoenvironmental indicators in the Taylor Group (Devonian) of Antarctica | journal = Palaeogeography, Palaeoclimatology, Palaeoecology | volume = 80 | issue = 3–4 | pages = 301–310 | doi = 10.1016/0031-0182(90)90139-X | bibcode = 1990PPP....80..301W }} * Great images of the different trace fossils</ref> The confusion was rectified when it was realised that HCS<ref name=Woolfe1993/> and the [[ichnofacies]] could in fact be marine.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
====Beacon heights orthoquartzite==== Only known in north.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/>
Sometimes just referred to as top 30m of Hatherton sst.<ref name=Woolfe1993/>
Well sorted and cemented. Grains medium to coarse. Trough cross-beds.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> ''[[Haplostigma]] irregulare'' - lycopod remnants. Constrain to early Middle Devonian.<ref name=Woolfe1993/> Contact on Hatherstone sandstone is sharp, irregular, and in places cobbly - so erosional.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/>
====Aztec siltstone==== The Aztec siltstone bears interbedded sandstones and fish-bearing shales (providing late Mid Devonian age). Palæosols abundant and well developed, implying subaerial periods.<ref name=Woolfe1994/>
Only known in north.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Top 7.5m contains dewatering structures - result of loading by tillites.<ref name=Isbell2003>{{cite journal | author1 = Isbell, J.L. | author2 = Lenaker, P.A. | author3 = Askin, R.A. | author4 = Miller, M.F. | author5 = Babcock, L.E. | year = 2003 | title = Reevaluation of the timing and extent of late Paleozoic glaciation in Gondwana: Role of the Transantarctic Mountains | journal = Geology | volume = 31 | issue = 11 | pages = 977–980 | doi = 10.1130/G19810.1 |bibcode = 2003Geo....31..977I }} * contains images of dewatering structures</ref> This implies that the sediments were not consolidated in Permian times, and indeed that the area did not undergo glaciation during the Carboniferous ice age.<ref name=Isbell2003/>
Minimum thickness 135m.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Coarse sands and finer muds; cross-bedded channels up to 12m wide.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Small and large roots.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> [[Psilophyte]]s, lycopod stems, logs.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/>
====Darwin tillite====
Base of Victoria group.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> Also known as Metschel tillite.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> Overlays Hatherton and Aztec<ref name=Woolfe1993/> unconformably,<ref name=Gevers1971/> resting on "Maya" erosion surface,<ref name=Woolfe1994/> which has only "slight" relief.<ref name=Pinet1971>{{cite journal |author1=PR Pinet |author2=DB Matz |author3=MO Hayes | year = 1971 | journal=Journal of Sedimentary Research | volume =41 | title = An Upper Paleozoic Tillite in the Dry Valleys, South Victoria Land, Antarctica: NOTES | doi = 10.1306/74D7236A-2B21-11D7-8648000102C1865D | issue=3 | pages=835–838 |bibcode = 1971JSedR..41..835P }}</ref> Underlying sands thumped by granitic clasts, which form load structures.<ref name=Isbell2003/>
This [[erosion surface]] was formed by downcutting streams, later scoured by glacial ice.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> [[Permian]] in age.<ref name=Kamp1982/> Erosion surface covered with pebbly mudstone.<ref name=Pinet1971/> Features rhythmic, varved layers, with some channel and sheet sandstones.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> Main unit is [[diamictite]].
====Misthound coal measure==== Part of Victoria group.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> Overlays tillite unconformably,<ref name=Gevers1971/> resting on "Pyramid" erosion surface which was formed by reworking of the tillite.<ref name=Woolfe1994/> Dominated by ''[[Gangamopteris]]''. Cross-bedded sandstones, with some mudstones, carbonaceous shales, and of course coal.
====Ellis formation==== Comprises a conglomerate, sand- and silt-stone.<ref name=Gevers1971/>
==Palæontology==
===Body fossils=== The Aztec sandstone contains units bearing body fossils of Fish:<ref name=Gevers1971/> [[Phyllolepid]] [[placoderms]],<ref>Allowing dating to late Mid Devonian</ref><ref name=Woolfe2004>{{cite journal | author = Woolfe, K.J. | year = 2004 | title = Cycles of erosion and deposition during the Permo-Carboniferous glaciation in the Transantarctic Mountains | journal = Antarctic Science | volume = 6 | issue = 1 | pages = 93–104 | doi = 10.1017/S095410209400012X | bibcode = 1994AntSc...6...93W }}</ref> and [[thelodonts]];<ref name=Turner2004>{{cite journal | author = Turner, S. |author2= Young, G.C. | year = 2004 | title = Thelodont scales from the Middle-Late Devonian Aztec Siltstone, southern Victoria Land, Antarctica | journal = Antarctic Science | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 89–105 | doi = 10.1017/S0954102092000142 | bibcode = 1992AntSc...4...89T }}</ref> abundant in fish beds; and [[conchostracan]]s.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
Also: Charred wood remnants,<ref name=GPDF/> and the plants ''[[Glossopteris]]''<ref name=Hamilton1963/> and ''[[Haplostigma]]''.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
Wood bears clear [[tree ring|ring]]s, so environment must have been very seasonal.<ref name=Hamilton1963/> Large enough to represent temperate climate, at least.<ref name=Hamilton1963/> Glacial just before Beacon deposition.<ref name=Hamilton1963/>
Nothing else though.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
===Trace fossils=== [[Image:Beacon-burrows.jpg|thumb|Burrows in the Beacon Supergroup.]]
Sparse below, but become common in Hatherton Sandstone. Changes from Skolithos-dominated facies to wide diversity and abundance, including vertical and horizontal burrows, and huge arthropod [[fossil trackway|trackway]]s.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> Size of arthropod tracks (<91 cm!) taken to imply that water must have been required for support.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> In Hatherton, ''Skolithos'' density decreases.
Present include:
*[[Fodinichnia]]: feeding burrows, probably of marine [[polychaete]]s, featuring evidence of rhythmic defecation.<ref name=Gevers1971/> **Narrow, sinuous, near-surface forms on flat bedding surfaces **Longer, larger forms, reaching 13 cm across and 1 m in length. *Walking [[fossil trackway|trackway]]s of arthropods ([[Repichnia]]).<ref name=Gevers1971>{{cite journal | author = Gevers, T.W. |author2= Frakes, L.A.|author3= Edwards, L.N.|author4= Marzolf, J.E. | year = 1971 | title = Trace Fossils in the Lower Beacon Sediments (Devonian), Darwin Mountains, Southern Victoria Land, Antarctica | journal = Journal of Paleontology | volume = 45 | issue = 1 | pages = 81–94 | jstor=1302754 }}</ref> **''[[Beaconites]] antarcticus'': Narrow, parallel grooves, about an inch apart, disappearing into elliptical pits; created by shovelling the surface sediment aside before burrowing into the sediment.<ref name=Gevers1971/> Occasionally branch.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> **Wider spaced grooves (~3 cm); small footprints visible. Implies many walking limbs and an approximately rectangular shape - reminiscent of the [[trilobite]]s.<ref name=Gevers1971/> ''B. barretti''? Extend laterally up to 1.7m; burrow "deeply" into sediment.<ref name="Bradshaw2007 ">{{cite journal | author = Bradshaw, M.A. |author2= Harmsen, F.J. | year = 2007 | title = The paleoenvironmental significance of trace fossils in Devonian sediments (Taylor Group), Darwin Mountains to the Dry Valleys, southern Victoria Land | journal = Antarctica: A Keystone in a Changing World--Online Proceedings of the 10 thISAES X, edited by AK Cooper and CR Raymond et al., USGS Open-File Report | volume = 1047 | url = http://pubs.usgs.gov/of/2007/1047/ea/of2007-1047ea133.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-04-22 }}</ref> Probably produced by a very different arthropod to ''B. antarcticus''.<ref name=Bradshaw2007/> **Large (~30 cm wide) trails with a scrape mark from a central tail. Three to four footprint pits diverge from these tracks at a high angle. The feet making the footprints had spines on their rears. These may have been formed by [[eurypterids]] but aren't a perfect match to known eurypterid trails; they may also have been formed by [[Xiphosura]]ns<ref name=Gevers1971/> *''[[Diplichnites]]'' trackways - double rows of fossils - previously attributed to marine trilobites. Clearly not - so perhaps annelids / myriapods?<ref name=Woolfe1990/> Here appear on metre-scale crossbeds: sub-fluvial dunes?<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
The presence of crawling traces in such well sorted sands is problematic. The arthropod trackways are thought to have been formed in shallow water, and supersaturated sand has a shallow angle of repose. Thus either a layer of organic matter, perhaps in the form of an algal slime, must have supported the sediment,<ref name=Gevers1971/> or the sediment must have been partially dry. In the context of subaerial features such as raindrop marks and desiccation cracks on associated horizons, the best explanation is that the trackways were formed on bedforms produced on a river bed, but while they were exposed by a low-flow period.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
*''[[Cruziana]]'' & ''[[Rusophycus]]'': thought to be formed by [[trilobite]]s, whose body fossils are only found in marine assemblages. Could they also be made by other arthropods, or could the lower parts of the Beacon sandstone have been marine? They have been found in many other non-marine instances.<ref name=Woolfe1990/> *''[[Skolithos]]'' - again, traditionally thought to be marine, but there are lots of examples where it isn't.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
====Ichnofacies==== {{main|ichnofacies}}
*''Scoyenia'' ichnofacies implies freshwater aquatic nature.<ref name=Woolfe1990/>
==Depositional environment== Sedimentological and palæontological data point to a shallow marine [[Sedimentary depositional environment|depositional environment]].<ref name=Gevers1971/>
The well-sorted nature of the unit suggests that it was probably deposited close to the shoreline, in a high energy environment.<ref name=Angino1962/> This is backed up by the absence of clay-sized particles, and the rounded, spherical<!--Both terms ARE necessary, neither redundant!--> shape of quartz grains.
Features, such as the presence of [[coal bed]]s and [[desiccation crack]]s, suggest that parts of the unit were deposited subaerially.<ref name=Angino1962/> [[Ripple mark]]s and [[cross bedding]] show that shallow water was also commonly present.<ref name=Angino1962/>
==Source rock==
* Too few minerals to come from local granites and schists, unless a long period of subaerial weathering preceded deposition.<ref name=Angino1962/> * Could have been transported; would have to be a long distance to produce such a clean sandstone.<ref name=Angino1962/>
==Thermal history== * Heat from burial modest.<ref name=Bernet2005>{{cite journal | doi = 10.1080/00288306.2005.9515125 | author = Bernet, M. |author2= Gaupp, R. | year = 2005 | title = Diagenetic history of Triassic sandstone from the Beacon Supergroup in central Victoria Land, Antarctica | journal = New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics | volume = 48 | issue = 3 | pages = 447–458 | url = http://www.rsnz.org/publish/nzjgg/2005/032-lo.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-04-22 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> * Heated to 160+° by intrusion of dolerite sills,<ref name=Elliott1963/> dykes and lenses during the early Jurassic, related to break up of Gondwana {{Ma|180}}.<ref name=Bernet2005/> - the [[Ferrar Dolerite]].<ref name=Gevers1971/> Reached T of 200-300 °C in places.<ref name=Bernet2005/> * Volatiles would have migrated outwards from the hot aureole, condensing when they reached rock cooler than their boiling point. This results in the "steam distillation" of the volatiles.<ref name=Elliott1963/>
==Utility==
===Biology=== * The rock is low in phosphorus,<ref name=Banerjee2000>{{cite journal | author = Banerjee, M. | year = 2000 | title = Phosphatase Activities of Endolithic Communities in Rocks of the Antarctic Dry Valleys | journal = Microbial Ecology | volume = 39 | issue = 1 | pages = 80–91 | doi = 10.1007/s002489900188 | pmid = 10790521 | last2 = Whitton | first2 = BA | last3 = Wynn-Williams | first3 = DD }}</ref> creating difficulties for organisms living on it. * Mostly supports lichens; has its own endogenous community
===Hydrocarbon potential=== *Great source: but nothing to trap oil.<ref name=Elliott1963/>
==Further reading== <ref name=Plume1982>{{cite book | author = Plume, R.W. | year = 1982 | title = Sedimentology and palaeocurrent analysis of the basal part of the Beacon Supergroup (Devonian (and older?) to Triassic) in south Victoria Land, Antarctica | editor = Craddock, C | publisher =University of Wisconsin Press, | location = Madison | booktitle= Antarctic Geoscience | isbn = }}</ref> <ref name=Geevers1982>{{cite book | author = Geevers TW & Twomey | year = 1982 | title = Sedimentology and palaeocurrent analysis of the basal part of the Beacon Supergroup (Devonian (and older?) to Triassic) in south Victoria Land, Antarctica | editor = Craddock, C | publisher =University of Wisconsin Press, | location = Madison | booktitle= Antarctic Geoscience | pages = 639–648 | isbn = }}</ref> <ref name=Sherwood1988>{{cite journal | author = Sherwood, A.M. |author2= Woolfe, K.J.|author3= Kirk, P.A. | year = 1988 | title = Geological mapping and preliminary paleoenvironmental interpretations of the Taylor Group in the knobhead area, Southern Victoria Land | journal = New Zealand Antarctic record | volume = 8 | issue = 2 | pages = 60–61 }}</ref> <ref name="Plume1978">{{cite journal|last=Plume |first=RW|year=1978|journal=New Zealand Journal of Geology & Geophysics |volume=21|pages=167–173|doi=10.1080/00288306.1978.10424048}}</ref> <ref>{{cite book |vauthors=Barrett PJ, Kohn BP |year=1975 |pages=15–35 |editor=Campbell KSW |booktitle=Gondwana Geology |publisher=ANU Press |location=Canberra }}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|author=Barrett, PJ|year=1979|journal=Proceedings of the 4th International Gondwana Symposium Calcutta 1977|pages= 478–480}}</ref> <ref>{{cite journal|author=Bradshaw MA|year=1981 |journal=New Zealand Journal Geology & Geophysics |volume=24|pages=615–652}}</ref> {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of Antarctica]] [[Category:Geology of Antarctica]] [[Category:Geologic formations of Antarctica]] [[Category:Geological supergroups]] [[Category:Fossil trackways]] [[Category:Trace fossils]]

{{short description|An approach to human geography that examines human behavior using a disaggregate approach}} '''Behavioral geography''' is an approach to [[human geography]] that examines human behavior using a disaggregate approach. Behavioral geographers focus on the [[cognitive process]]es underlying [[spatial reasoning]], [[decision making]], and [[behavior]]. In addition, behavioral geography is an ideology/approach in human geography that makes use of the methods and assumptions of [[behaviorism]] to determine the [[cognitive]] processes involved in an individual's perception of or response and reaction to their environment<ref> Hemakumara, GPTS. and Rainis, R. 2018. Spatial behaviour modelling of unauthorised housing in Colombo, Sri Lanka. KEMANUSIAAN the Asian Journal of Humanities25(2): 91–107, https://doi.org/10.21315/kajh2018.25.2.5
Spatial Behaviour Modelling of Unauthorised Housing in Colombo, Sri Lanka | Request PDF. Available from: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/327864214_Spatial_Behaviour_Modelling_of_Unauthorised_Housing_in_Colombo_Sri_Lanka [accessed Sep 27 2018].</ref>.
Behavioral geography is that branch of human science, which deals with the study of cognitive processes with its response to its environment, through behaviorism.
==Issues== Because of the name it is often assumed to have its roots in [[behaviorism]]. While some behavioral geographers clearly have roots in behaviorism<ref name=Norton01>Norton, W. (2001). Initiating an affair human geography and [[behavior analysis]]. ''The Behavior Analyst Today'', 2 (4), 283–290 [http://www.baojournal.com]</ref><ref name=Norton02>Norton, W. (2002) Explaining Landscape Change: Group Identity and Behavior. ''The Behavior Analyst Today'', 3 (2), 155–160 [http://www.baojournal.com BAO]</ref> due to the emphasis on cognition, most can be seen as cognitively oriented. Indeed, it seems that behaviorism interest is more recent<ref name=Glass07>Glass, J.E. (2007). Behavior analytic grounding of sociological [[social constructionism]]. ''The Behavior Analyst Today'', 8 (4), 426–433 [http://www.baojournal.com BAO]</ref> and growing.<ref name=Norton01/> This is particularly true in the area of human landscaping.
Behavioral geography draws from early behaviorist works such as [[Edward C. Tolman|Tolman]]'s concepts of "[[cognitive map]]s". More [[Cognitive geography|cognitively oriented]], behavioral geographers focus on the cognitive processes underlying spatial reasoning, decision making, and behavior. More behaviorally oriented geographers are materialists and look at the role of basic learning processes and how they influence the landscape patterns or even group identity.<ref name=Norton97>Norton, W. (1997). Human geography and behavior analysis: An application of behavior analysis to the evolution of human landscapes. ''The Psychological Record'', 47, 439–460</ref>
The cognitive processes include environmental perception and cognition, wayfinding, the construction of cognitive maps, place attachment, the development of attitudes about space and place, decisions and behavior based on imperfect knowledge of one's environs, and numerous other topics.
The approach adopted in behavioral geography is closely related to that of [[psychology]], but draws on research findings from a multitude of other disciplines including economics, [[sociology]], [[anthropology]], [[transportation planning]], and many others.
== The Social Construction of Nature == [[Nature]] is the world which surrounds us, including all life (plants, animals, organisms, humans, etc.) and physical features. [[Social constructionism|Social Construction]] is the way that human beings process the world around us in our minds. According to [[Plato|Plato's]] 'Classical Theory of Categorization', humans create categories of what they see through experience and imagination.<ref name=":05">Gerber, J. (1997). Beyond Dualism — the social construction of nature and the natural ''and'' social construction of human beings. Retrieved from http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.925.2585&rep=rep1&type=pdf</ref> Social constructionism, therefore, is this characterization that makes language and [[semantics]] possible.<ref name=":05"/> If these experiences and imageries are not placed into categories, then the human ability to think about it becomes limited.<ref name=":05"/>
The social construction of nature looks to question different truths and understandings for how people treat nature, based on when and where someone lives. In academic circles, researchers look at how truths exist ([[ontology]]) and how truths are justified ([[epistemology]]).<ref name=":05"/> Construction is both a process and an outcome, where people's understandings of the word nature can be both [[literal and figurative language|literal]] and [[metaphor]]ical,<ref name=":12">Demerit, D. (2002). What is the 'social construction of nature'? A typology and sympathetic critique. Retrieved from https://is.muni.cz/el/1423/podzim2010/SOC165/Demeritt_2002_-_Social_Constr_of_Nature.pdf</ref> such as through giving it a human quality ([[Mother Nature]]).<ref name=":22">Williams, R. (1983). Keyword: A vocabulary of culture and society. New York, NY: Oxford University Press.</ref> It can also be used to discredit [[science]] or philosophy.<ref name=":12"/>
As a subset of behavioral geography, the social construction of nature also includes [[environmental ethics]] and [[Value (ethics)|values]], which affect how humans treat, and interact with, the [[natural environment]]. It incorporates ideas from [[environmental science]], [[ecology]], [[sociology]], [[geography]], [[biology]], [[theology]], [[philosophy]], [[psychology]], [[politics]], [[economics]], and other disciplines, to bring together the social, cultural and environmental dimensions of life. Social constructionism uses a lot of ideas from [[Western world]] thinking, but it is also incorporates truths from other [[world view]]s, such as the [[Traditional knowledge|Traditional Knowledge]] of Aboriginal groups, or more specifically [[ecofeminism]]<ref name=":32">Merchant, C. (2003). Reinventing Eden: The Fate of Nature in Western Culture. New York, NY: Routledge.</ref><ref name=":4">Shiva, V. (1988). ''Staying Alive: Women, Ecology, and Development'' (1st ed.). London, UK: Zed Books Ltd.</ref> and [[cosmology]]<ref name=":4" /> in [[India]] or [[Ubuntu philosophy|ubuntu]]<ref>Grange, L. L. (2012). Ubuntu, Ukama, Environment and Moral Education. ''Journal of Moral Education, 41''(3), 329-340.</ref> philosophy in [[Africa]], for example. It is also related to [[Postmodernism, or, the Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism|postmodernism]]<ref name=":53">Proctor, J. (1998). The Social Construction of Nature: Relativist Accusations, Pragmatist and Critical Realist Responses. Retrieved from http://www.geog.ucsb.edu/~jproctor/pdf/AAGAnnals1998.pdf</ref> and the concept of the [[Anthropocene]],<ref>Monastersky, R. (2015). Anthropocene: The Human Age. ''Nature, 519(7542)'', 143-147.</ref> that views humans as a force that is redirecting the [[geological history of Earth]],<ref name=":22"/> destroying nature.<ref>Cronon, W. (1995). The Trouble with Wilderness; or, Getting Back to the Wrong Nature. In ''Uncommon Ground: Rethinking the Human Place in Nature'' (pp. 69-90). New York, NY: W. W. Norton & Co.</ref>
=== The Role of Linguistics === [[File:Raymond_Williams_At_Saffron_Walden.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Raymond_Williams_At_Saffron_Walden.jpg|thumb|Raymond Williams, author of ''Keywords: A vocabulary of culture and society (1983)''.]] There are many ways of understanding and interpreting nature.<ref name=":22"/> According to [[Raymond Williams]], there are three ways to give meaning to (or define) nature: # Nature as a quality, character or process<ref name=":22" /> (e.g. human nature) # Nature as a force<ref name=":22" /> (e.g. weather) # Nature as the material world<ref name=":22" /> (e.g. the physical environment) According to [[Raymond Williams]], language plays a role in how we understand, interpret, and give meaning to nature.<ref name=":22" /> This is how multiple truths can be valid at the same time.<ref name=":05"/><ref name=":22" />
=== The Role of Mental Maps === Humans have the ability to create images of their environments through experiences in their mind.<ref name=":6">Lynch, D. (1960). The Image of the City. MA: Harvard University Press.</ref> These experiences allow us to create [[Mental mapping|mental maps]] where we can create memories associated to space.<ref name=":6" /> It is a two-way process where the environment provides suggestions for what should be seen, and then the observer gives meaning with those suggestions.<ref name=":6" />
These images have three parts: # An identity<ref name=":6" /> # A pattern<ref name=":6" /> # A [[Pragmatism|practical]] or [[emotion]]al meaning<ref name=":6" /> According to [[Kevin A. Lynch|Kevin Lynch]], the environmental images (or mental maps) that we make can either be weak or strong, where the process is ongoing and never stops.<ref name=":6" />
=== The Role of Science === [[Science]] occurs at many [[dimension]]s and scales that do not consider culture, but can be motivated by politics, economics and ethics.<ref name=":7">Pedynowski, D. (2003). Science(s) - which, when and whose? Probing the metanarrative of scientific knowledge in the social construction of nature. Retrieved from http://0-eds.b.ebscohost.com.mercury.concordia.ca/eds/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=15017498-bcd5-409d-b7ed-3d2141dad610%40sessionmgr101</ref> Scientific knowledge consists of [[concept]]s and [[analysis]], and is a way to represent nature.<ref name=":53"/>
According to [[Michel Foucault]], a truth does not have to be close to reality for it to be worth something or have power.<ref name=":7" /> For [[Carolyn Merchant]], science can only be given power if a truth is interpreted as having worth.<ref name=":7" />
== Schools of Thought ==
[[Relativism]] is important in the social construction of nature, as all truths are relative to the perspective they are coming from. There are two schools of thought on how the social construction of nature is relative: # [[Critical realism (philosophy of the social sciences)|Critical Realism]] (being realistic)<ref name=":53"/> # [[Pragmatism]] (being practical)<ref name=":53" /> Critical realists reject the idea of relativism and rely more on natural sciences.<ref name=":53" /> Pragmatists have no set opinion on the matter and rely on [[social science]] and ethics, instead.<ref name=":53" />
According to [[Richard Rorty]], relativism is relevant to pragmatism in three ways: # Every belief is equally valid<ref name=":53" /> # There is no criteria for what a truth can be<ref name=":53" /> # That any truth can be justified by the society it comes from<ref name=":53" /> According to [[Gilbert White]], pragmatism has four main assumptions: # That human existence is based on putting labor into the land<ref name=":53" /> # That the idea of owning anything is a [[wikt:conception|conception]]<ref name=":53" /> # That humans learn from their experiences<ref name=":53" /> # That engagement of the publics is what allows for commitments<ref name=":53" /> Richard Rorty also associated three characteristics to pragmatism: # That all theories characterize some form of truth<ref name=":53" /> # That there is not difference between what can and should be done when it comes to the truth<ref name=":53" /> # That knowledge is constrained by the conversations we have<ref name=":53" /> Being pragmatic is the more accepted school of thought for social construction being a relative concept.<ref name=":53" />
== Historical Overview == [[File:Rachel_Carson_w.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rachel_Carson_w.jpg|thumb|Rachel Carson, author of ''Silent Spring (1962)''.]]
=== Recovery Narratives === * '''1500s''': [[Francis Bacon]] (that human intervention in nature is needed to gain back the [[Garden of Eden]] on Earth)<ref name=":32"/> * '''1600s''': [[René Descartes]] (that the world is a machine we can control)<ref name=":05"/><ref name=":32" /> * '''1600s''': [[John Locke]] (that [[private property]] makes humans civilized)<ref name=":32" /> * '''1700s''': [[Adam Smith]] (that [[capitalism]] will bring progress)<ref name=":32" /> * '''Present-day:''' The [[Christian mythology|Christian narrative]] and the narrative of the [[Scientific revolution|Scientific Revolution]] have merged to become the 'Recovery Narrative of Western Culture'<ref name=":32" />
=== Transitions in Thought === * '''1500s-1600s''': The belief that man is responsible for environmental problems<ref name=":8">Lowenthal, D. (1990). Awareness of Human Impacts: Changing Attitudes and Emphases. In B.L. Turner(Ed.), ''The earth as transformed by human action: global and regional changes in the biosphere over the past 300 years'' (pp. 121-135). Cambridge: Press Syndicate of the University of Cambridge.</ref> * '''1700s-1800s''': The idea that progress is attained through controlling nature<ref name=":8" /> * '''Mid-1800s''': The realization that humans are having unintended impacts on the environment<ref name=":8" /> * '''1800s-1900s''': The belief that technology has all the solutions to our problems<ref name=":8" /> * '''1920s-1930s''': The belief that technology is destroying nature<ref name=":8" /> * '''1950s-1960s''': The belief that humans risk being annihilated if they do not control technological impacts<ref name=":8" /> * '''1960s-1970s''': The public awakening of human impacts on the environment with the publication of [[Rachel Carson]]'s ''[[Silent Spring]]''<ref name=":8" /> * '''1980s''': The belief that no matter the costs, unrestricted growth is needed for progress<ref name=":8" /> * '''1987''': The spreading of public awareness of impacts with the publication of the [[Brundtland Commission]] Report: ''[[Our Common Future]]''<ref name=":8" />
== How Nature becomes Socially Constructed == [[File:Vandana_shiva_20070610.jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Vandana_shiva_20070610.jpg|thumb|Vandana Shiva, author of ''Staying Alive: Women, Culture, and Development (1988)''.]] Nature can be socially constructed by both culturally interpreting and physically shaping the environment.<ref name=":9">Peterson, A. (1999). Environmental Ethics and the Social Construction of Nature. Retrieved from https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/54464729/Peterson.SocialConstructionNature.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1517194179&Signature=VH%2F5cQL2wkJVCJqk1%2BJZTifMdIY%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DEnvironmental_Ethics_and_the_Social_Cons.pdf</ref> This can happen in three ways: # Using non-human symbols to represent nature ([[Totem]]ism)<ref name=":9" /> # Using non-human animals to relate to nature ([[Animism]])<ref name=":9" /> # Viewing nature as an '[[Other (philosophy)|Other]]' ([[Naturalism (philosophy)|Naturalism]]) <ref name=":9" /> Constructions can also be categorized by giving them meaning through the process of [[embodied cognition|embodiment]],<ref name=":05"/> which has three components: # The '[[Habitus (sociology)|habitus]]' (the individual)<ref name=":05" /> # The practice it originates from (the culture)<ref name=":05" /> # An associated [[Taxon|taxonomic group]] (i.e. [[homo sapiens]])<ref name=":05" /> No matter how nature becomes socially constructed, though, the process itself is limited by three dimensions: # The physical dimension<ref name=":05" /> # The mental dimension<ref name=":05" /> # The social dimension<ref name=":05" /> The physical dimension is limited to the human body, where the brain is responsible for creating and selecting thoughts.<ref name=":05" /> The mental dimension is used to understand the physical dimension and is limited to human logic.<ref name=":05" /> The social dimension needs moral and [[social order]] and is used to give meaning to both what is physically present and what is culturally constructed.<ref name=":05" /> All three dimensions must be present and linked to be able to socially construct nature.<ref name=":05" />
== Criticism on the Social Construction of Nature == The social construction of nature has room for improvement in four main areas: # By giving more importance to how realities are culturally constructed through social interactions<ref name=":12"/> # By acknowledging that all science should be analyzed by the same standard<ref name=":12" /> # By gaining a better understanding of the role language plays in constructionism<ref name=":12" /> # By giving more importance to how truths exist and how they are justified, using [[Actor–network theory|Actor-Network Theory]]<ref name=":12" />
== See also == * [[Cognitive geography]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Navboxes |list= {{Geography topics}} {{Human geography}} {{Environmental social science}} }}

revision.text:
[[File:Thimpu-71 (8213044189).jpg|thumb|The clock tower]] '''Clock Tower Square''' has a tower with four clock faces located in [[Thimphu]], capital of [[Bhutan]]. It is a famously known landmark in Thimphu. There are many shops, hotels and restaurants surrounding the square.
==Location==
The clock tower square is located below ''Norzin Lam'', Thimphu above the national football stadium in the heart of the capital.
==Architecture==
[[File:Clock Tower square, Norzin Lam, Thimphu.jpg|thumb|Clock Tower square, Norzin Lam, Thimphu]]
The Clock-tower has a typical Bhutanese architectural outlook with rich Bhutanese carvings and paintings. There are traditional hand crafted dragon with golden painting on all the four faces of the tower which symbolizes the county as an independent dragon kingdom. The tower has beautiful paintings and carvings of flowers which add more magnificence to the tower. The shops, restaurants and hotels in the clock tower square have a blend of fine traditional and modern architectural Bhutanese design with multi-coloured wood frontages, small arched windows, and sloping roofs. The buildings around the square are all small three storied structures.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bhutan: a land in frozen time|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/country_profile/54627.stm|publisher=BBC news|accessdate=2013-04-23}}</ref>
==Other attractions==
Water fountains and traditional Bhutanese Mani Lhalhor (prayer wheels) make the place an ideal location to catch up with [[Thimphu]]. Prayer wheels are seen almost everywhere around the country which is a Bhutanese way of life and belief that turning them brings good luck.<ref name="Brown, p.98">[[Thimphu#cite note-Brown.2C p. 98-15]]</ref> The square often serves as a platform for various events and activities such as fund-raising events, movie award ceremony, trade fairs, live musical shows and many more.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trade Fair|url=http://www.handicraftsbhutan.org/activities.html|publisher=Handicraft Association of Bhutan}}</ref> There is also a small play ground opposite to the tower where kids can play. The square has even played host to the Indo-Bhutan friendship car rally.<ref>BHUTAN360 . (2012, May 9). Retrieved from http://bhutan-360.com/attractions-in-thimphu/</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=4th INDO – BHUTAN FRIENDSHIP CAR RALLY 2011|url=http://www.fcras.com/4th_indo_bhutan_2011.html|publisher=FRIENDSHIP CAR RALLY ASSOCIATION}}</ref><ref>[[Thimphu#cite note-Brown.2C p. 98-15]]</ref>
==References== <references />
{{Coord|27.4703|N|89.6397|E|type:landmark_region:BT|display=title}}
[[Category:Buildings and structures in Bhutan]] [[Category:Geography of Bhutan]] [[Category:Squares in Asia]] [[Category:Thimphu]] [[Category:Clock towers]]

{{Time zones of Africa}} {{As of|2018}}, [[daylight saving time]] (DST) is permanently observed in [[Morocco]], previously time was advanced to [[UTC+01:00|UTC+1]] at 02:00 on the last Sunday of March, and reverted to [[UTC±0|UTC]] ([[standard time]]), defined as [[Greenwich Mean Time]] locally, at 03:00 on the last Sunday of October. This practise was continued through October 2018, after which clocks were permanently advanced. An exception was made during the month of [[Ramadan]] during which clocks reverted to UTC (standard time).<ref name="TD 20130928">{{Cite web| url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/morocco-ends-dst-2013.html| title=Morocco extends DST to October 27, 2013| publisher=timeanddate.com| date=28 September 2013| accessdate=1 October 2013}}</ref><ref name="Maroc 20130928">{{cite web|url=http://www.maroc.ma/fr/actualites/lhoraire-dete-gmt1-maintenu-jusquau-27-octobre-2013|title=L'horaire d'été (GMT+1) maintenu jusqu'au 27 octobre 2013|date=28 September 2013|publisher=Royaume de Maroc|language=French|accessdate=October 1, 2013}}</ref>
For 2014, these dates were: :* 29 March – advance to UTC+1 (DST) :* 28 June – return to UTC (start of Ramadan)<ref name="MMSP">{{ cite web | url = http://www.mmsp.gov.ma/fr/actualites.aspx?id=586 | title = Retour à l’heure légale du Royaume (GMT). | publisher = Moroccan Ministry of the Modernisation of the Public Sector | date = | accessdate = 2014-10-26 | language = fr }}</ref> :* 2 August – advance to UTC+1 (end of Ramadan)<ref name="MMSP" /> :* 26 October – return to UTC (standard time)
==History== {{Anchor|Dates in 2012}}<!--Preserving old section header in case of inlinks--> * '''2008:''' DST began on 1 June and ended on 1 September. This was the first time Morocco had used daylight saving time since 1978.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/morocco-daylight-saving.html |title=Morocco revives daylight saving schedule in 2008 |publisher=Timeanddate.com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> * '''2009:''' DST began on 1 June and ended on 21 August.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/morocco-starts-dst-2009.html |title=Morocco’s Daylight Saving Time Starts June 1, 2009 |publisher=Timeanddate.com |date=17 March 2009 |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> * '''2010:''' DST began on 2 May and ended on 8 August, just before [[Ramadan]], as had been the case in recent years.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/morocco-starts-dst-2010.html |title=Morocco Starts Daylight Saving Time May 2, 2010 |publisher=Timeanddate.com |date=13 April 2010 |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref> * '''2011:''' DST began on 2 April at midnight and ended on 31 July at midnight.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.map.ma/fr/sections/accueil/l_heure_legale_au_ma/view |title=L'heure légale au Maroc sera avancée de 60 mn à partir de dimanche prochain |publisher=Map.ma |date= |accessdate=2011-03-31}}{{Dead link|date=October 2013}}</ref> * '''2012:''' On Thursday, 8 March 2012, the Moroccan Cabinet approved a bill for the permanent adoption of DST with predictable start and finish dates. However, before the start of DST, they changed it to advance to UTC+1 at 02:00 on the last Sunday of April, and return to UTC at 03:00 on the last Sunday of September, with the exception of the holy month of Ramadan, during which DST will not be observed.<ref name=Ramadan2012>{{cite web|title=Retour à l’heure légale du Royaume (GMT)|url=http://www.mmsp.gov.ma/fr/actualites.aspx?id=288|publisher=The Kingdom of Morocco, Ministry of Public Functions and Administration Modernisation|accessdate=2012-07-17|pages=1|language=French}}</ref><ref>http://www.maroc.ma/PortailInst/Fr/evenements/Le+Conseil+de+gouvernement.htm</ref> As a result, the time changes in 2012 were: :* 29 April – advance to UTC+1 (DST)<ref name=2012DSTStart>{{cite web|title=Changement de l’heure légale du Royaume|url=http://www.mmsp.gov.ma/fr/actualites.aspx?id=250|publisher=The Kingdom of Morocco, Ministry of Public Functions and Administration Modernisation|accessdate=2012-07-17|language=French|date=2012-04-19}}</ref> :* 20 July – return to UTC (start of Ramadan) :* 20 August – advance to UTC+1 (end of Ramadan) :* 30 September – return to UTC (standard time)
* '''2013:''' DST followed the 2012 law at first:
:* 28 April – advance to UTC+1 (DST) :* 7 July – return to UTC (start of Ramadan) :* 10 August – advance to UTC+1 (end of Ramadan)
However, on Saturday, 28 September, the government announced a change in policy, which moved the end of DST from the last Sunday in September (which was to be the next day) to the last Sunday in October (27 October). At the same time, they moved the beginning of DST back to the last Sunday in March (next 30 March 2014). As usual, advancements to DST (UTC+1) occurred at 02:00 and returns to standard time (UTC) occurred at 03:00.<ref name="TD 20130928"/>
:*'''2018:''' Switch to permanent DST <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mmsp.gov.ma/ar/actualites.aspx?id=1598|title=الاستمرار في العمل بالساعة الإضافية : (GMT + 1).|last=|first=|date=2018-10-26|website=|publisher=وزارة الوظيفة العمومية وتحديث الإدارة|language=Arabic|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2018-10-26}}</ref> : On 26 October in a government decree, the government changed UTC offset for Morocco Time Zone, Morocco Time Zone now use [[UTC+01:00]] all year around. but in fact, this decree mandates permanent daylight saving time. ::
