{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 2em; width: 20em; font-size: 90%;" cellspacing="3" |- | colspan="2" style="text-align: center; font-size: larger;" | '''Geography of New Zealand''' |- | colspan="2" style="padding: 1em 0; text-align: center;" | [[File:Satellite image of New Zealand in December 2002.jpg|250px|New Zealand Satellite image]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Continent''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Region''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Oceania]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Coordinates''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | {{coord|41|S|174|E|type:country}} |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Area''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[List of countries by area|Ranked 75th]]
267,710 km²
103,738 miles²
97.9% land
2.1% water |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Coastline''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[1 E7 m|15,134 km]]
9,398 miles |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Borders''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | 0 km |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Highest point''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Aoraki / Mount Cook]]
{{convert|3,724|m|ft|abbr=on}} |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Lowest point''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Taieri Plains]]
−2 m |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Longest river''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Waikato River]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Largest lake''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | [[Lake Taupo]] |- style="vertical-align: top;" |'''Climate''' |style="padding-right: 1em;" | Mostly [[temperate]], with some areas being [[Tundra]], and [[Subantarctic climate|Subantarctic]] |} [[New Zealand]] (''{{lang|mi|[[Aotearoa]]}}'') is an [[island country]] located in the south-western [[Pacific Ocean]], near the centre of the [[water hemisphere]]. It is a long and narrow country and comprises [[List of islands of New Zealand|around 600 islands]]. The two main islands by size are the [[North Island]] (or ''Te Ika-a-Māui'') and the [[South Island]] (or ''Te Waipounamu''), separated by the [[Cook Strait]]; the third-largest island, [[Stewart Island]] (or ''Rakiura''), is located {{convert|30|km}} off the tip of the South Island across [[Foveaux Strait]]. Significantly smaller islands include [[Waiheke Island]], [[Chatham Island]], [[Great Barrier Island]] and more, although many are uninhabited. New Zealand's landscape ranges from the [[fiord]]-like [[sound (geography)|sounds]] of the southwest to the sandy beaches of the far north. The South Island is dominated by the [[Southern Alps]] while a [[North Island Volcanic Plateau|volcanic plateau]] covers much of the central North Island. Temperatures rarely fall below 0 °C or rise above 30 °C and conditions vary from wet and cold on the South Island's [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]] to dry and continental a short distance away across the mountains and near [[subtropical]] in the northern reaches of the North Island. New Zealand's varied landscape has appeared in [[television show]]s, such as ''[[Xena: Warrior Princess]]''. An increasing number of feature films have also been filmed there, including the [[The Lord of the Rings (film series)|''Lord of the Rings'' trilogy]]. The country is situated about {{convert|2000|km}} southeast of [[Australia]] across the [[Tasman Sea]], its closest neighbours to the north being [[New Caledonia]], [[Tonga]] and [[Fiji]]. It is the southernmost nation in [[Oceania]]. The relative proximity of New Zealand north of [[Antarctica]] has made the South Island a gateway for scientific expeditions to the continent. ==Physical geography== {{Hatnote|[[File:commons-logo.svg|12px|link=|alt=]] See also: [[commons:Atlas of New Zealand|Atlas of New Zealand]] at [[Wikimedia Commons]]}} [[File:Turbid Waters Surround New Zealand.jpg|thumb|right|Strong winds in the Cook Strait produce high waves which erode the shore, as shown in this image]] ===Overview=== [[File:Map New Zealand-en.svg|thumb|left|An annotated [[raised-relief map]]]] New Zealand is located in the [[Pacific Ocean|South Pacific Ocean]] at {{coord|41|S|174|E|type:country}}, near the centre of the [[water hemisphere]].{{cite book|last1=Hobbs|first1=Joseph J.|title=World Regional Geography|date=2008|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=0495389501|page=9|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yAgGHnENHjoC&pg=PA9|accessdate=16 August 2017|language=en}} It is a long and narrow country, extending {{convert|1600|km|mi}} along its north-north-east axis with a maximum width of {{convert|400|km|mi}}.{{cite book|title=Heinemann New Zealand atlas|publisher=[[Heinemann (publisher)|Heinemann Publishers]]|first=D. W.|last=McKenzie|year=1987|isbn=0-7900-0187-X}} New Zealand consists of a [[List of islands of New Zealand|large number of islands]], estimated around 600.{{cite web |url=http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/nearshore-islands |title=Nearshore islands |encyclopedia=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |first=Eileen |last=McSaveney |date=24 September 2007}} The islands give it {{convert|15,134|km|mi|abbr=on}} of coastline and extensive marine resources. New Zealand claims the fifth-largest [[Exclusive economic zone of New Zealand|exclusive economic zone]] in the world, covering over {{convert|4,000,000|sqkm}} (1.5 million sq mi), more than 15 times its land area.Ministry for the Environment. 2005. Offshore Options: Managing Environmental Effects in New Zealand's Exclusive Economic Zone. [http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/oceans/offshore-options-jun05/html/page3.html Introduction] The [[South Island]] is the largest land mass of New Zealand, and is the [[List of islands by area|12th-largest island]] in the world. The island is divided along its length by the [[Southern Alps]]. The east side of the island has the [[Canterbury Plains]] while the [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]] is famous for its rough coastlines, high rainfall, very high proportion of native [[forest|bush]], and [[glacier]]s.{{cite web |last1=McSaveney |first1=Eileen |title=Landscapes – overview |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/landscapes-overview |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018}} The [[North Island]] is the second-largest island, and the 14th-largest in the world. It is separated from the South Island by the [[Cook Strait]], with the shortest distance being {{convert|23|km}}.{{citation |last1=McLintock |first1=A. H. |authorlink1=Alexander Hare McLintock |title=Cook Strait - The Sea Floor |date=1966|work=[[An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand]]}}{{cite web |author=The Editors of Encyclopaedia Britannica |title=Cook Strait {{!}} strait, New Zealand |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Cook-Strait |work=Encyclopedia Britannica |accessdate=9 October 2018 |language=en}} The North Island is less mountainous than the South Island, although a series of narrow mountain ranges form a roughly north-east belt that rises up to {{convert|1,700|m}}. Much of the surviving forest is located in this belt, and in other mountain areas and rolling hills.{{cite web|last1=Walrond|first1=Carl|title=Natural environment – The bush and its plants|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/natural-environment/page-4|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=February 2005}} The North Island has many isolated [[Mount Taranaki|volcanic peaks]] and New Zealand's [[Lake Taupo|largest lake]]. Besides the North and South Islands, the five largest inhabited islands are [[Stewart Island]], [[Chatham Island]], [[Great Barrier Island]] (in the [[Hauraki Gulf]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.aucklandcity.govt.nz/auckland/introduction/hauraki/default.asp |title=Hauraki Gulf islands |publisher=[[Auckland City Council]] |accessdate=13 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225020855/http://www.aucklandcity.govt.nz/auckland/introduction/hauraki/default.asp |archivedate=25 December 2010 }} [[D'Urville Island (New Zealand)|d'Urville Island]] (in the [[Marlborough Sounds]]){{cite web|last=Hindmarsh |year=2006 |url=http://www.historic.org.nz/en/Publications/HeritageNZMagazine/HeritageNz2006/HNZ06-DiscoveringDUrville.aspx |title=Discovering D'Urville |publisher=Heritage New Zealand |accessdate=13 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511071150/http://www.historic.org.nz/en/Publications/HeritageNZMagazine/HeritageNz2006/HNZ06-DiscoveringDUrville.aspx |archivedate=11 May 2011 }} and [[Waiheke Island]] (about {{convert|22|km|mi|0|abbr=on}} from central [[Auckland]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.auckland-coastguard.org.nz/Information/Distance+Tables.html|title=Distance tables |publisher=Auckland Coastguard |accessdate=2 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110123074649/http://www.auckland-coastguard.org.nz/Information/Distance+Tables.html |archivedate=23 January 2011}} ====Extreme points==== {{main article|List of extreme points of New Zealand}} [[File:Forty-Fours or Motuhara Islands.jpg|thumb|The Forty-Fours viewed from the north; the leftmost islet is the easternmost point of New Zealand.]] The phrase "From Cape Reinga to The Bluff" is frequently used within New Zealand to refer to the extent of the whole country.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=bb2Q2uO-FbEC&pg=PA59|title=A Land of Two Halves|last1=Bennett|first1=Joe|date=2005|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=9780743263573|page=59|language=en}} [[Cape Reinga]] is northwesternmost tip of the [[Aupouri Peninsula]], at the northern end of the North Island. [[Bluff, New Zealand|Bluff]] is [[Invercargill]]'s port, located near the southern tip of the South Island, below the [[46th parallel south]]. However, the extreme points of New Zealand are actually located in several [[New Zealand outlying islands|outlying islands]].{{cite web|url=https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/the-extreme-points-of-new-zealand.html|title=The Extreme Points Of New Zealand|date=29 March 2018|accessdate=11 June 2018}} The points that are farther north, south, east or west than any other location in New Zealand are as follows: *The northernmost point is in [[Nugent Island]] in the [[Kermadec Islands]] ({{coord|-29.231667|-177.869167}}). *The southernmost point is [[Jacquemart Island]] in the [[Campbell Island group]] ({{coord|-52.619444|169.125833}}). *The easternmost point is situated in a group of islands within the Chatham Islands called the [[Forty-Fours]] ({{coord|-43.963306|-175.831410}}). *The westernmost point is [[Cape Lovitt]] on [[Auckland Island]] ({{coord|-50.799838|165.870128}}). ====Antipodes==== {{See also|Antipodes#Cities}} [[File:New Zealand antipodes.png|thumb|New Zealand is antipodal to points of the North Atlantic, the Iberian Peninsula and Morocco.|alt=|right]] New Zealand is largely antipodal to the [[Iberian Peninsula]] of Europe.{{cite web|url=https://www.antipodesmap.com|title=Antipodes Map – Tunnel to the other side of the world|website=www.antipodesmap.com|language=en|accessdate=16 August 2017}} The northern half of the South Island corresponds to [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] and northern [[Portugal]].{{Better source|date=November 2018}} Most of the North Island corresponds to central and southern Spain, from [[Valladolid]] (opposite the southern point of the North Island, [[Cape Palliser]]), through [[Madrid]] and [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] to [[Córdoba, Spain|Cordoba]] (directly antipodal to [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]]), [[Lorca, Spain|Lorca]] (opposite East Cape), [[Málaga]] (Cape Colville), and [[Gibraltar]]. Parts of the [[Northland Peninsula]] oppose [[Morocco]], with [[Whangarei]] nearly coincident with [[Tangiers]]. The antipodes of the Chatham Islands lie in [[France]], just north of the city of [[Montpellier]]. The [[Antipodes Islands]] were named for their supposed antipodal position to Britain; although they are the closest land to the true antipodes of Britain, their location 49°41′S 178°48′E is directly antipodal to a point a few kilometres to the east of [[Cherbourg]] on the north coast of France.{{Cite web|url=http://www.howderfamily.com/blog/antipodes-islands/|title=Antipodes Islands|work=Twelve Mile Circle|accessdate=6 January 2011}} In Europe the term "Antipodes" is often used to refer to New Zealand and Australia (and sometimes other South Pacific areas),{{cite book|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=b1eOAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA165|title=The Idea of the Antipodes: Place, People, and Voices|last1=Goldie|first1=Matthew Boyd|date=2010|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135272180|page=165|language=en}} and "[[wikt:antipodean|Antipodeans]]" to their inhabitants. ===Geology=== {{main article|Geology of New Zealand|Volcanism in New Zealand}} [[File:New Zealand geology map with key.jpg|thumb|left|]] [[File:Zealandia-Continent map en.svg|thumb|left|Topography of [[Zealandia (continent)|Zealandia]], the submerged continent, and the two tectonic plates]] New Zealand is part of [[Zealandia]], a [[microcontinent]] nearly half the size of Australia that gradually submerged after breaking away from the [[Gondwana]]n supercontinent.{{Cite journal|last1=Wallis|first1=G. P.|last2=Trewick|first2=S. A.|year=2009|title=New Zealand phylogeography: evolution on a small continent|journal=Molecular Ecology|volume=18|issue=17|pages=3548–3580|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2009.04294.x|pmc=|pmid=19674312}} Zealandia extends a significant distance east into the Pacific Ocean and south towards Antarctica. It also extends towards [[Australia (continent)|Australia]] in the north-west. This submerged continent is dotted with topographic highs that sometimes form islands. Some of these, such as the main islands (North and South), Stewart Island, New Caledonia, and the Chatham Islands, are settled. Other smaller islands are eco-sanctuaries with carefully controlled access. [[File:Lake taupo landsat.jpg|thumb|right|The scalloped bays indenting Lake Taupo's northern and western coasts are typical of large volcanic [[caldera]] margins. The caldera they surround was formed during the huge [[Oruanui eruption]].]] The New Zealand landmass has been uplifted due to transpressional [[plate tectonics|tectonics]] between the [[Indo-Australian Plate]] and [[Pacific Plate|Pacific]] plates (these two plates are grinding together with one riding up and over the other).{{cite web|url=http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/en/sea-floor-geology/2|title=Sea floor geology – Active plate boundaries|last1=Lewis|first1=Keith|last2=Nodder|first2=Scott|date=March 2009|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=14 August 2017|last3=Carter|first3=Lionel}} This is the cause of New Zealand's numerous earthquakes and volcanoes. To the east of the North Island the Pacific Plate is forced under the Indo-Australian Plate. The North Island of New Zealand has widespread back-arc volcanism as a result of this [[subduction]]. There are many large volcanoes with relatively frequent eruptions. There are also several very large [[calderas]], with the most obvious forming [[Lake Taupo]]. Taupo has a history of incredibly powerful eruptions, with the [[Oruanui eruption]] approx. 26,500 years ago ejecting {{convert|1170|km3}} of material and causing the downward collapse of several hundred square kilometers to form the lake.{{cite web|url=https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/the-power-of-taupo/|title=The Power of Taupo|website=www.nzgeo.com|publisher=New Zealand Geographic|language=en-NZ|accessdate=15 August 2017}} The [[Hatepe eruption|last eruption]] occurred {{circa|180 CE}} and ejected at least 100 cubic kilometers of material, and has been correlated with red skies seen at the time in [[Roman Empire|Rome]] and [[Han dynasty|China]].{{cite journal|last=Wilson|first=C. J. N.|authorlink=Colin J. N. Wilson|author2=Ambraseys, N. N.|author3=Bradley, J.|author4=Walker, G. P. L.|year=1980|title=A new date for the Taupo eruption, New Zealand|url=|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=288|issue=5788|pages=252–253|bibcode=1980Natur.288..252W|doi=10.1038/288252a0|accessdate=|quote=}}The associated geothermal energy from this volcanic area is used in numerous [[hydrothermal circulation|hydrothermal power plants]].Matthew Hall (2004) [http://www.med.govt.nz/upload/24445/geothermal.pdf Existing and Potential Geothermal Resource for Electricity Generation]. Ministry for Economic Development. Some volcanic places are also famous tourist destinations, such as the [[Rotorua]] [[geyser]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.rotorua.nz.com/geothermal.aspx|title=Rotorua Geothermal Sites – Geothermal Sites in Rotorua New Zealand|publisher=New Zealand on the Web|accessdate=15 August 2017}} The subduction direction is reversed through the South Island, with the Indo-Australian Plate forced under the Pacific Plate. The transition between these two different styles of continental collision occurs through the top of the South Island. This area has significant uplift and many [[active fault]]s; large earthquakes are frequent occurrences here. The most powerful in recent history, the M8.3 [[1855 Wairarapa earthquake|Wairarapa earthquake]], occurred in 1855. This earthquake generated more than {{convert|6|m}} of vertical uplift in places, and caused a localised tsunami. Fortunately casualties were low due to the sparse settlement of the region. In 2013, the area was rattled by the M6.5 [[Seddon earthquake]], but this caused little damage and no injuries.{{cite web|url=http://www.geonet.org.nz/earthquake/2013p543824|title=M 6.5 Cook Strait Sun, Jul 21 2013|publisher=GeoNet|language=en|accessdate=15 August 2017|quote=A magnitude 6.5 earthquake occurred 20 km east of Seddon, New Zealand on Sun Jul 21 2013 5:09 PM}} New Zealand's capital city, [[Wellington]], is situated in the centre of this region. The subduction of the Indo-Australian Plate drives rapid uplift in the centre of the South Island (approx. {{convert|10|mm}} per year). This uplift forms the Southern Alps. These roughly divide the island, with a narrow wet strip to the west and wide and dry plains to the east. The resulting [[orographic]] rainfall enables the hydroelectric generation of most of the country's electricity. A significant amount of the movement between the two plates is accommodated by lateral sliding of the Indo-Australian Plate north relative to the Pacific Plate. The plate boundary forms the nearly {{convert|800|km}} long [[Alpine Fault]]. This fault has an estimated rupture reoccurrence interval of ~330 years, and last ruptured in 1717 along {{convert|400|km}} of its length. It passes directly under many settlements on the West Coast of the South Island and shaking from a rupture would likely affect many cities and towns throughout the country. The rapid uplift and high erosion rates within the Southern Alps combine to expose high grade [[greenschist]] to [[amphibolite]] [[facies]] rocks, including the gemstone [[pounamu]] ([[jade]]). Geologists visiting the West Coast can easily access high-grade [[metamorphic rock]]s and [[mylonite]]s associated with the Alpine Fault, and in certain places can stand astride the fault trace of an active plate boundary.{{cite web|url=https://academic.oup.com/petrology/article-abstract/13/3/457/1591862/Progressive-Metamorphism-of-Metabasic-Rocks-from?redirectedFrom=PDF|title=Progressive Metamorphism of Metabasic Rocks from the Haast Schist Group of Southern New Zealand|last1=COOPER|first1=A. F.|date=1 October 1972|website=Journal of Petrology|pages=457–492|language=en|bibcode=1972JPet...13..457C|doi=10.1093/petrology/13.3.457|accessdate=15 August 2017}} To the south of New Zealand the Indo-Australian Plate is subducting under the Pacific Plate, and this is beginning to result in [[back-arc basin|back-arc]] volcanism. The youngest (geologically speaking) volcanism in the South Island occurred in this region, forming the [[Solander Islands]] (<2 million years old).{{cite journal|last1=Harrington|first1=H. J.|last2=Wood|first2=B. L.|year=1958|title=Quaternary andesitic volcanism at the Solander Islands|journal=New Zealand Journal of Geology and Geophysics|volume=1|issue=3|pages=419–431|doi=10.1080/00288306.1958.10422772|issn=0028-8306}} This region is dominated by the rugged and relatively untouched [[Fiordland]], an area of flooded glacially carved valleys with little human settlement. ===Mountain, volcanoes and glaciers=== {{See also|List of mountains of New Zealand by height|List of volcanoes in New Zealand}} The South Island is much more mountainous than the North, but shows fewer manifestations of recent volcanic activity. There are 18 peaks of more than {{convert|3000|m|ft|abbr=off}} in the Southern Alps, which stretch for {{convert|500|km}} down the South Island.{{cite book|last1=Kisch|first1=Conrad|title=Destination. New Zealand|date=2009|publisher=Gyldendal Uddannelse|isbn=9788702075847|page=11|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Ne1Gh4nEkM0C&pg=PA11|language=en}} The closest mountains surpassing it in elevation are found not in Australia, but in [[New Guinea]] and [[Antarctica]]. As well as the towering peaks, the Southern Alps include huge glaciers such as [[Franz Josef Glacier|Franz Josef]] and [[Fox Glacier|Fox]].{{cite web |last1=McSaveney |first1=Eileen |title=Glaciers and glaciation |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/glaciers-and-glaciation |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zelaand |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=24 September 2007}} The country's highest mountain is [[Aoraki / Mount Cook]]; its height since 2014 is listed as {{convert|3724|m|ft|abbr=off}} (down from {{convert|3764|m|ft|abbr=on}} before December 1991, due to a rockslide and subsequent erosion).{{cite news|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/9616590/Aoraki-Mt-Cook-shrinks-by-30m|title=Aoraki/Mt Cook shrinks by 30m|work=Stuff.co.nz|date=16 January 2014}} The second highest peak is [[Mount Tasman]], with a height of {{convert|3,497|m}}.{{cite web |last1=Dennis |first1=Andy |title=Mountains - South Island mountains |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/photograph/14299/highest-peaks-of-the-southern-alps |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=2 February 2017}} The [[North Island Volcanic Plateau]] covers much of central North Island with volcanoes, [[lava plateau]]s, and [[crater lake]]s. The three highest volcanoes are [[Mount Ruapehu]] ({{convert|2,797|m}}), [[Mount Taranaki]] ({{convert|2,518|m}}) and [[Mount Ngauruhoe]] ({{convert|2,287|m}}). Ruapehu's major eruptions have historically been about 50 years apart,{{cite web| title=Crater Lake| url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/parks-and-recreation/tracks-and-walks/central-north-island/ruapehu/mount-ruapehu-crater-climb/| author=New Zealand Department of Conservation | accessdate=2006-10-23}} in 1895, 1945 and 1995–1996. The [[1886 eruption of Mount Tarawera]], located near [[Rotorua]], was New Zealand's largest and deadliest eruption in the last 200 years, killing over 100 people.{{cite web|title=Eruption of Mt Tarawera|url=https://nzhistory.govt.nz/eruption-of-mt-tarawera|publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=21 August 2017}} Another long chain of mountains runs through the North Island, from Wellington to East Cape. The ranges include [[Tararua Range|Tararua]] and [[Kaimanawa Range|Kaimanawa]].{{cite web |last1=Dennis |first1=Andy |title=Mountains |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/mountains |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=2 February 2017}} The lower mountain slopes are covered in native forest. Above this are shrubs, and then [[Tussock grasslands of New Zealand|tussock grasses]]. [[Alpine tundra]] consists of cushion plants and herbfields; many of these plants have white and yellow flowers.{{cite web |last1=Dennis |first1=Andy |title=Mountains - Alpine plants and animals |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/mountains/page-4 |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=2 February 2017}} {{wideimage|Southern Alps from Hamilton Peak.jpg|1000px|A portion of the Southern Alps mountain chain, as viewed from Hamilton Peak}} {{wide image|CentralPlateauNZ.jpg|1000px|View of the Central Plateau from the Desert Road showing the three active peaks: Snow-capped Ruapehu (left), conical Ngauruhoe (centre) and broad-domed Tongariro (right)}} ===Caves=== {{main article|Caving in New Zealand|List of caves in New Zealand}} New Zealand's cave systems have three main origins, the chemical weathering of limestone by water ([[karst]]), [[Lava cave|lava caves]] and erosion by waves ([[Sea cave|sea caves]]). Therefore the distribution of limestone, marble ([[Metamorphic rock|metamorphosed]] limestone) and volcanoes defines the location of caves in inland New Zealand.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=DwOqDQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=Geomorphology+of+New+Zealand&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiT7Y3k8vfeAhUBEnIKHbzQDooQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=Geomorphology%20of%20New%20Zealand&f=false|title=New Zealand Landscape: Behind the Scene|last=Williams|first=Paul|date=2017-05-18|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780128125656|language=en}} The main regions of karst topography are the [[Waitomo District]]{{cite web|url=http://www.newzealand.com/au/waitomo-caves/|title=Things to see and do in Waitomo Caves, New Zealand|website=www.newzealand.com|publisher=Tourism New Zealand|language=en|accessdate=16 August 2017}} and [[Takaka Hill]] in the [[Tasman District|Tasman district]]. Other notable locations are on the [[West Coast, New Zealand|West Coast]] ([[Punakaiki]]), the [[Hawke's Bay Region|Hawkes Bay]] and [[Fiordland]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.realjourneys.co.nz/en/experiences/glowworm-caves/te-anau-glowworm-caves/|title=Te Anau Glowworm Caves: Explore Te Anau's unique glowworm caves|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en}} Lava caves ([[lava tubes]]) usually form in [[pahoehoe]] lava flows, which are less viscus and typical formed from [[basalt]]. When an eruption occurs the outer layer of the lava flow hardens, while the interior remain liquid. The liquid lava flows out as it is insulated by the hardened crust above. These caves are found where there are relatively recent basaltic volcanoes in New Zealand, such as the [[Auckland volcanic field|Auckland Volcanic Field]] particularly on [[Rangitoto Island|Rangitoto]], [[Mount Eden|Mt Eden]] and [[Matukutururu]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzgeo.com/stories/secret-passages/|title=The lava caves hidden beneath suburban Auckland|work=New Zealand Geographic|access-date=2018-12-01|language=en-NZ}} The distribution of sea caves is more sporadic, with their location and orientation being controlled by weakness in the underlying rock. As cave systems take many thousands of years to develop they can now be isolated from the water that formed them, whether through change in sea level or groundwater flow.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=XrtVlwEACAAJ&dq=west+coast+walking&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiy8q-_9_feAhURWCsKHUtLCEAQ6AEIKjAA|title=West Coast Walking: A Naturalist's Guide|last=Wilson|first=Kerry-Jayne|date=2013|publisher=Canterbury University Press|year=|isbn=9781927145425|location=|pages=137|language=en}} If as a cave grows it breaks through to the surface somewhere else it becomes a [[natural arch]], like those near [[Karamea]] ([[Oparara Basin Arches|Oparara Arches]]). ===Rivers and lakes=== {{main article|Rivers of New Zealand|Lakes of New Zealand}} The proportion of New Zealand's area (excluding [[estuaries]]) covered by rivers, lakes and ponds, based on figures from the New Zealand Land Cover Database,{{cite web|title=Historical environmental reporting|url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/more/environmental-reporting/reporting-act/about-reporting-act|publisher=Ministry for the Environment of New Zealand|accessdate=21 November 2016|date=2007}} is (357526 + 81936) / (26821559 – 92499–26033 – 19216) = 1.6%. If estuarine open water, mangroves, and [[Herbaceous plant|herbaceous]] saline vegetation are included, the figure is 2.2%. [[File:Lake Taupo and Waikato River aerial view.jpg|thumb|The Waikato River flowing out of Lake Taupo]] The mountainous areas of the North Island are cut by many rivers, many of which are swift and unnavigable. The east of the South Island is marked by wide, [[braided river]]s such as the [[Wairau River|Wairau]], [[Waimakariri River|Waimakariri]] and [[Rangitata River|Rangitātā]]; formed from glaciers, they fan out into many strands on gravel plains. The [[Waikato River|Waikato]], flowing through the North Island, is the New Zealand's longest river, with a length of {{convert|425|km}}.{{cite web|last1=Young|first1=David|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/rivers|title=Rivers|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=16 August 2017|date=24 September 2007}} New Zealand's rivers feature [[List of waterfalls of New Zealand|hundreds of waterfalls]]; the most visited set of waterfalls are the [[Huka Falls]] that drain [[Lake Taupo]].{{cite web |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/waterfalls |last1=Phillips |first1=Jock |title=Waterfalls |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018 |date=24 September 2007}} Lake Taupo, located near the centre of the North Island, is the largest lake by surface area in the country. It lies in a [[caldera]] created by the [[Oruanui eruption]], the largest eruption in the world in the past 70,000 years. There are 3,820 lakes with a surface area larger than one [[hectare]].{{cite web|title=List of lakes of New Zealand|url=http://thegrid.co.nz/list-of-lakes-of-new-zealand/|publisher=TheGrid|accessdate=21 November 2016|date=12 February 2014}} Many lakes have been used as reservoirs for [[hydroelectric]] projects.About 58% of New Zealand's electricity was hydroelectric in 2002. Veronika Meduna. '[http://www.TeAra.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/ClimateAndAtmosphere/WindAndSolarPower/en Wind and solar power] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819125921/http://www.teara.govt.nz/EarthSeaAndSky/ClimateAndAtmosphere/WindAndSolarPower/en |date=19 August 2007 }}', Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand, updated 21 September 2007. ===Climate=== {{main article|Climate of New Zealand|Climate change in New Zealand}} [[File:New Zealand snow.jpg|thumb|left|Central Plateau in winter]] The main factors that influence New Zealand's climate are the temperate [[latitude]], with [[prevailing winds|prevailing westerly winds]]; the [[ocean]]ic environment; and the mountains, especially the Southern Alps. The climate is mostly temperate with mean temperatures ranging from {{convert|8|°C|°F|abbr=on}} in the South Island to {{convert|16|°C|°F|abbr=on}} in the North Island.From NIWA Science [http://www.niwascience.co.nz/edu/resources/climate/overview/ climate overview]. January and February are the warmest months, July the coldest. New Zealand does not have a large temperature range, apart from central Otago, but the weather can change rapidly and unexpectedly. Near [[subtropical]] conditions are experienced in [[Northland Peninsula|Northland]]. Most settled, lowland areas of the country have between 600 and 1600 mm of [[precipitation (meteorology)|rainfall]], with the most rain along the west coast of the South Island and the least on the east coast of the South Island and interior basins, predominantly on the [[Canterbury Plains]] and the Central Otago Basin (about 350 mm {{abbreviation|PA|per annum; annually}}). [[Christchurch]] is the driest city, receiving about {{convert|640|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rain per year, while [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]] is the wettest, receiving more than twice that amount at 1325 mm PA, followed closely by Auckland. The wettest area by far is the rugged Fiordland region, in the south-west of the South Island, which has between 5000 and 8000 mm of rain per year, with up to 15,000 mm in isolated valleys, amongst the highest recorded rainfalls in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.niwa.co.nz/__data/assets/file/0006/44268/rain.xls|title=Mean monthly rainfall|publisher=National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research|format=XLS|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110503221956/http://www.niwa.co.nz/__data/assets/file/0006/44268/rain.xls|archivedate=3 May 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}} [[File:Scorching Bay.jpg|thumb|right|[[Scorching Bay]], Wellington]] The [[UV index]] can be very high and extreme in the hottest times of the year in the north of the North Island. This is partly due to the country's relatively little [[air pollution]] compared to many other countries and the high sunshine hours. New Zealand has very high sunshine hours with most areas receiving over 2000 hours per year. The sunniest areas are Nelson/Marlborough and the Bay of Plenty with 2400 hours per year.{{cite web|url=http://www.niwascience.co.nz/__data/assets/file/0006/44655/sunshine.xls|title=Mean monthly sunshine hours|publisher=National Institute of Water and Atmospheric Research|format=XLS|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081015102420/http://www.niwascience.co.nz/__data/assets/file/0006/44655/sunshine.xls|archivedate=15 October 2008|accessdate=16 August Island| ''Stewart Island / Rakiura]]''}} {{ Location map~ | New Zealand | marksize=0| lat_deg=38 |lat_min=48 |lat_sec=25 | lat_dir=S |lon_deg=176 |lon_min=00 |lon_sec=28 | lon_dir=E | label=[[Lake Taupo|''Lake Taupo]]'' |label_size=80}} }} ===Political geography=== New Zealand has no land [[border]]s. However, the [[Ross Dependency]], its claim in Antarctica, nominally borders the [[Australian Antarctic Territory]] to the west and [[Marie Byrd Land|unclaimed territory]] to the east. Most other countries do not recognise [[territorial claims in Antarctica]].{{cite web |title=Who owns Antarctica? |url=http://www.antarctica.gov.au/about-antarctica/people-in-antarctica/who-owns-antarctica |publisher=Australian [[Department of the Environment and Energy]] |accessdate=10 October 2018 |date=8 September 2017}} New Zealand [[wikt:proper|proper]] is subdivided into [[regions of New Zealand|sixteen regions]]: seven in the South Island and nine in the North.{{cite web|title=New Zealand – A regional profile|url=http://www.stats.govt.nz/browse_for_stats/population/migration/nz-a-regional-profile.aspx|publisher=Statistics New Zealand|accessdate=15 August 2017|language=en-nz}} They have a geographical link with regional boundaries being based largely on [[drainage basin]]s.{{cite book|title=OECD Territorial Reviews OECD Territorial Reviews: The Metropolitan Region of Rotterdam-The Hague, Netherlands|date=2016|publisher=OECD Publishing|isbn=9789264249387|page=169|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PkR_CwAAQBAJ&lpg=PA169|language=en}} Among the regions, eleven are administered by regional authorities (top tier of [[local government in New Zealand|local government]]), while five are [[unitary authorities]] that combine the functions of regional authorities and those of [[territorial authorities]] (second tier). Regional authorities are primarily responsible for [[environmental resource management]], [[land management]], regional [[transport in New Zealand|transport]], and [[biosecurity]] and pest management. Territorial authorities administer local roading and reserves, [[waste management]], building consents, the land use and subdivision aspects of resource management, and other local matters. The [[Chatham Islands]] is not a region, although its council operates as a region under the [[Resource Management Act 1991|Resource Management Act]]. There are a number of [[New Zealand outlying islands|outlying islands]] that are not included within regional boundaries. The [[Kermadec Islands|Kermadecs]] and the [[New Zealand Subantarctic Islands|subantarctic islands]] are inhabited only by a small number of [[New Zealand Department of Conservation|Department of Conservation]] staff.{{cite web|title=NZ Outlying Islands Regional Information & Travel Information|url=http://www.tourism.net.nz/new-zealand/about-new-zealand/regions/nz-outlying-islands/regional-information.html|website=www.tourism.net.nz|publisher=New Zealand Tourism Guide|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}} ===Population geography=== {{see also|Demographics of New Zealand}} [[File:Aerial view of Auckland.jpg|thumb|An aerial view of the [[Auckland]] urban area, showing its location on the [[Hauraki Gulf]]]] The South Island contains a little under one-quarter of the population. Over three-quarters of New Zealands population live in the North Island, with one-third of the total population living in the [[Auckland Region]]. Auckland is also the fastest growing region, accounting for 46 percent of New Zealand's total population growth. Most [[Māori people|Māori]] live in the North Island (87 percent), although a little under a quarter (24 percent) live in Auckland. New Zealand is a predominantly urban country, with {{Decimals|({{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Main urban areas|y}}|R}}+{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Secondary urban areas|y}}|R}}+{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Minor urban areas|y}}|R}})/{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|New Zealand|y}}|R}}*100|1}} percent of the population living in an [[urban areas of New Zealand|urban area]]. About {{Decimals|{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Main urban areas|y}}|R}}/{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|New Zealand|y}}|R}}*100|1}} percent of the population live in the 17 main urban areas (population of 30,000 or more) and {{Decimals|({{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Auckland|y}}|R}}+{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Wellington|y}}|R}}+{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Christchurch|y}}|R}}+{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|Hamilton|y}}|R}})/{{formatnum:{{NZ population data|New Zealand|y}}|R}}*100|1}} percent live in the four largest cities of Auckland, Christchurch, Wellington, and Hamilton.{{NZ population data||||y}} New Zealand's peoples have been defined by their immigrant origin, the on going process of adaptation to a new land, being changed and changing those who came before. This process has lead to a distinct distribution of culture across New Zealand. Here language and religion are used as markers for the far richer concept of culture. These metrics unfortunately exclude the political rural-urban divide{{Cite web|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/97283075/election-shows-ruralurban-divide-shrinking-not-growing.html|title=Election shows rural-urban divide shrinking, not growing|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}} and also the full effects of the Christchurch earthquakes on New Zealand's cultural distribution.{{Cite web|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/7783450/10-600-people-leave-Christchurch|title=10,600 people leave Christchurch|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-11-28}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=Nfu9CwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=christchurch+ruptures&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjD-IH_6ffeAhUQTn0KHXHCCIgQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=christchurch%20ruptures&f=false|title=Christchurch Ruptures|last=Pickles|first=Katie|date=2016-03-15|publisher=Bridget Williams Books|isbn=9780908321308|language=en}} New Zealand's language varies spatially both within and between ethnic groups. There are many sub dialects of the [[Māori language]]—the most pronounced division being between the northern and southern tribes.{{Cite news|url=https://www.radionz.co.nz/news/te-manu-korihi/250479/warning-minority-dialects-could-be-lost|title=Warning minority dialects could be lost|date=2014-07-24|work=Radio New Zealand|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-nz}} While migration (typically from north to south) was constant throughout the 16–18th centuries, the south maintained a distinct culture largely due to lack of cultivation possible at that latitude. Māori is still spoken more commonly (3.5 percent of the New Zealand population{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nz.html|title=Australia - Oceania :: New Zealand — The World Factbook - Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}}) in areas with large Māori populations ([[Gisborne District|Gisborne]], [[Bay of Plenty]] and [[Northland Peninsula|Northland]]).{{Cite web|url=http://socialreport.msd.govt.nz/cultural-identity/maori-language-speakers.html#regional-differences|title=Māori language speakers: The Social Report 2016 – Te pūrongo oranga tangata|website=socialreport.msd.govt.nz|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-28}} English, the dominant language of New Zealand (89.8 percent), is spoken with regional [[Accent (sociolinguistics)|accents]] relating to the origin of immigrants; for example Scottish and English 19th century immigration in [[Southland, New Zealand|Southland]] and [[Canterbury, New Zealand|Canterbury]] respectively.{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.canterbury.ac.nz/insiders/2016/11/10/what-is-the-southland-accent/|title=What is the Southland accent? - The Insider's Guide to UC {{!}} Tūpono|date=2016-11-09|work=The Insider's Guide to UC {{!}} Tūpono|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/1966/new-zealand-speech/page-11|title=THE SOUTHLAND DIALECT|last=Hare|first=McLintock, Alexander|access-date=2018-11-28|last2=Wellington.|first2=Arnold Wall, C.B.E., B.A.(CAMB.), M.A.(LOND.), D.LITT(N.Z.), F.R.S.TAS. (1869–1966), Professor Emeritus, University of Canterbury, and Author.Harold William Orsman, M.A.(N.Z.), Lecturer in English, Victoria University of|language=en|last3=Taonga|first3=New Zealand Ministry for Culture and Heritage Te Manatu}} This has also occurred with more recent immigration, with a wide variety of accents being common in larger cities where immigrant groups have preferentially settled. These immigrant groups change location with time and accents fade over generations.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11886666|title=When does Asian come to mean Kiwi?|last=@LincolnTanNZH|first=Lincoln Tan Lincoln Tan is the New Zealand Herald’s diversity, ethnic affairs and immigration senior reporter lincoln tan@nzherald co nz|date=2017-07-08|work=NZ Herald|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=m1ArDwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=old+asian+new+asian&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiU_PnW6vfeAhXGWisKHSC_A_oQ6AEIKjAA#v=onepage&q=old%20asian%20new%20asian&f=false|title=Old Asian, New Asian|last=Ng|first=K. Emma|date=2017-07-10|publisher=Bridget Williams Books|isbn=9780947518516|language=en}} A wide variety of other languages make up the remaining approximately 6 percent of New Zealanders—with [[Samoan language|Samoan]], Hindi, French and various Chinese dialects being the most common.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nz.html|title=Australia - Oceania :: New Zealand — The World Factbook - Central Intelligence Agency|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}} These minority foreign languages are concentrated in the main cities, particularly Auckland where recent immigration groups have settled.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=JVlug5Vn2eUC&oi=fnd&pg=PA271&dq=new+zealand+sign+language&ots=feq4t9KLAl&sig=0_ghuwg36FWdqPW2V1gVR4f8Nls#v=onepage&q=new%20zealand%20sign%20language&f=false|title=Languages of New Zealand|last=Bell|first=Allan|last2=Harlow|first2=Ray|last3=Starks|first3=Donna|date=2005|publisher=Victoria University Press|isbn=9780864734907|language=en}} === Agricultural geography === {{See also|Agriculture in New Zealand}} A relatively small proportion of New Zealand's land is [[arable land|arable]] (1.76%), and permanent crops cover 0.27% of the land. {{convert|7,210|km2}} of the land is [[irrigation|irrigated]].{{cite web|title=The World Factbook|date=2015|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]|isbn=9780160925535|page=537–542|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=1-4ZxpxT3GAC&pg=PA540|language=en}} As the world's largest exporter of sheep, New Zealand's agricultural industry focuses primarily on [[pastoral farming]], particularly dairy and beef, as well as lambs. Dairy, specifically, is their top export. {{Cite web|url=https://www.newzealandnow.govt.nz/resources/working-in-dairy-farming|title=Working in Dairy Farming {{!}} Guide for Migrants {{!}} New Zealand Now|website=www.newzealandnow.govt.nz|language=en|access-date=2018-11-22}} In addition to pastoral farming, fisherman harvest mussels, oysters and salmon, and horticulture farmers grow [[kiwifruit]], as well as peaches, nectarines, etc.{{Cite web|url=https://www.newzealand.com/sg/article/not-just-sheep-all-about-farming-in-new-zealand/|title=Not just sheep! All about farming in New Zealand|publisher= Tourism New Zealand|website=www.newzealand.com|language=en-sg|access-date=2018-11-13}} New Zealand's distance from world markets and spatial variation in rainfall, elevation and soil quality have defined the geography of its agriculture industry. As of 2007, almost 55 percent of New Zealand's total land area was being used for farming, which is standard compared to most developed countries. Three-fourths of it was pastoral land using for raising sheep, beef, deer, etc. The amount of farmland has decreased since 2002.{{Cite web|url=http://archive.stats.govt.nz/browse_for_stats/snapshots-of-nz/Measuring-NZ-progress-sustainable-dev-%20approach/sustainable-development/land-use.aspx|title=Measuring New Zealand’s Progress Using a Sustainable Development Approach: 2008|website=archive.stats.govt.nz|language=en-nz|access-date=2018-11-13}} New Zealand's isolated location has simultaneously lead to fewer [[Pest (organism)|pests]] and an agriculture industry with a greater susceptibility to introduced diseases and pests.{{cite journal|last1=Goldson|first1=SL|last2=Bourdôt|first2=GW|last3=Brockerhoff|first3=EG|last4=Byrom|first4=AE|last5=Clout|first5=MN|last6=McGlone|first6=MS|last7=Nelson|first7=WA|last8=Popay|first8=AJ|last9=Suckling|first9=DM|last10=Templeton|first10=MD|title=New Zealand pest management: current and future challenges|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of New Zealand|volume=45|issue=1|year=2015|pages=31–58|issn=0303-6758|doi=10.1080/03036758.2014.100034}} A major concern for New Zealand farmers is the rapidly growing wild rabbit population. Wild rabbits have been an agricultural issue for a while, since their introduction to the country in the 1930s. They cause significant damage to farm lands: eating the grass, crops, and causing soil degradation. Many farmers are worried about their livelihoods and the effects that the rabbits will have on food supply and trade, as their numbers are quickly growing out of control. An illegal rabbit-killing virus called the [[rabbit haemorrhagic disease]] virus (RHDV) was released in 1997 by a group of vigilante farmers, and was very effective initially.{{Cite web|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/101797178/hopes-nationwide-release-of-k5-rabbit-virus-will-kill-more-than-40-of-the-population.html|title=Hopes nationwide release of K5 rabbit virus will kill more than 40% of the population|website=Stuff|language=en|access-date=2018-11-13}} After twenty years, however, the rabbits became immune to it. To help desperate farmers, a new strain of the virus was released in March 2018, a Korean form of the strain called the K5 virus, or RHDV1-K5. This virus was introduced with the goal of exterminating 40 percent of the rabbit population. The new virus works much faster than the last one, expected to kill rabbits within two to four days of exposure. The virus has become a subject of debate among animal rights activists, due to the inhumane manner in which it kills the rabbits. However, farmers unanimously seem to be very grateful for the release of the virus.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-43221704|title=Why NZ is releasing a rabbit-killing virus|date=2018-02-28|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-GB}}[[File:New Zealand - Landscape - 8674.jpg|thumb|Rural landscape close to Mt Ruapehu]] Almost half of New Zealand's climate change emissions are generated by greenhouse gases, mainly methane and nitrous oxide, which come from farming and agriculture. Organisms that grow inside of grazing animals' stomachs turn New Zealand's grass into methane. The increase of carbon dioxide in the air helps the plants to grow faster, but the long-term effects of climate change threaten farmers with the likelihood of more frequent and severe floods and droughts.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nzherald.co.nz/the-country/news/article.cfm?c_id=16&objectid=11751990|title=Farmers react to climate change|last=Stowell|first=Laurel|work=NZ Herald|access-date=2018-11-13|language=en-NZ|issn=1170-0777}} Growers of kiwifruit, a major export in the horticulture industry of New Zealand, have experienced difficulties as a result of climate change. The recent warm winters are not providing the adequate cool temperatures needed for the flowering of kiwifruit, and has resulted in a reduction of the yield sizes. The recent droughts are also decreasing apple production by causing sunburns and a lack of water available for irrigation. In contrast, the [[Dairy farming in New Zealand|dairy industry]] has not been affected, and has actually adjusted well to the effects of climate change.{{Cite journal|last=Kenny|first=Gavin|date=September 2001|title=Climate Change: Likely Impacts on New Zealand Agriculture|url=https://www.mfe.govt.nz/sites/default/files/impacts-agriculture-sep01.pdf|journal=Ministry for the Environment|volume=|pages=|via=}} ==Natural hazards== Flooding is the most regular natural hazard.{{cite web|last1=McSaveney|first1=Eileen|title=Floods – New Zealand’s number one hazard|url=https://www.teara.govt.nz/en/floods/page-1|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=16 August 2017|date=1 August 2017}} Few regions have escaped winter floods. Settlements are usually close to hill-country areas which experience much higher rainfall than the lowlands due to the [[Orographic precipitation|orographic]] effect. Mountain streams which feed the major rivers rise rapidly and frequently break their banks covering farms with water and silt. Close monitoring, excellent weather forecasting, stopbanks, multiple hydropower dams, river dredging and reafforestation programmes in hill country have ameliorated the worst effects. New Zealand [[List of earthquakes in New Zealand|experiences around 14,000 earthquakes a year]],[http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/latest/200712211308/building_checks_continue_after_gisborne_earthquake Radio NZ news] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127063516/http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/latest/200712211308/building_checks_continue_after_gisborne_earthquake |date=27 January 2012 }} report on [[2007 Gisborne earthquake]] some in excess of [[earthquake magnitude|magnitude]] 7 (M7). Since the 2010, several large (M7, M6.3, M6.4, M6.2) and shallow (all <7 km) earthquakes have occurred immediately beneath Christchurch.{{cite web|last1=Nicholls|first1=Paul|title=Christchurch Quake Map – Earthquakes since September 4 2010|url=http://www.christchurchquakemap.co.nz/all|website=www.christchurchquakemap.co.nz|accessdate=15 August 2017}} These have resulted in 185 deaths, widespread destruction of buildings and significant liquefaction.{{cite web|title=Christchurch earthquake kills 185: 22 February 2011|url=https://nzhistory.govt.nz/page/christchurch-earthquake-kills-185|publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage|accessdate=15 August 2017|date=12 April 2017}} These earthquakes are releasing distributed stress in the Pacific plate from the ongoing collision with the Indo-Australian plate to the west and north of the city. Volcanic activity is most common on the central North Island Volcanic Plateau. [[Tsunamis affecting New Zealand]] are associated with the [[Pacific Ring of Fire]].{{cite web |title=Volcanoes - Pacific Ring of Fire |url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/interactive/8692/the-pacific-ring-of-fire |publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |accessdate=11 June 2018}} Droughts are not regular and occur mainly in Otago and the Canterbury Plains and less frequently over much of the North Island between January and April. Forest fires were rare in New Zealand before the arrival of humans.{{citation|author1=Dennys Guild|author2=Murray Dudfield|title=A history of fire in the forest and rural landscape in New Zealand Part 1, pre-''Maori and pre-European influences''|url=http://nzjf.org.nz/free_issues/NZJF54_1_2009/5C127D1A-CDFF-4cde-B272-23362D00A078.pdf|work=New Zealand Institute of Forestry|date=2009|accessdate=16 August 2017}} Fire bans exist in some areas in summer.{{cite web|title=Fire management|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/our-work/fire-management/|website=www.doc.govt.nz|publisher=New Zealand Department of Conservation|accessdate=16 August 2017|language=en}} ==Environment and ecology== {{main article|Environment of New Zealand|Conservation in New Zealand}} {{see also|Biodiversity of New Zealand|Fauna of New Zealand|Flora of New Zealand}} [[File:Water pollution sign on the Waimakariri River.JPG|thumb|Water pollution sign on the [[Waimakariri River]]]] New Zealand's geographic isolation for 80 million years{{Cite journal | last1 = Cooper | first1 = R. | last2 = Millener | first2 = P. | doi = 10.1016/0169-5347(93)90004-9 | title = The New Zealand biota: Historical background and new research | journal = Trends in Ecology & Evolution | volume = 8 | issue = 12 | pages = 429 | year = 1993 | pmid = | pmc = }} and island [[biogeography]] has influenced evolution of the country's species of [[fauna|animals]], [[fungus|fungi]] and [[flora|plants]]. Physical isolation has not caused biological isolation, and this has resulted in a dynamic evolutionary ecology with examples of very distinctive plants and animals as well as populations of widespread species.Trewick SA, Morgan-Richards M. 2014. New Zealand Wild Life. Penguin, New Zealand. {{ISBN|9780143568896}}{{Cite book | last=Lindsey | first=Terence | last2=Morris | first2=Rod | title=Collins Field Guide to New Zealand Wildlife | publisher=[[HarperCollins]] (New Zealand) Limited | year=2000|page=14|isbn=978-1-86950-300-0}} Evergreens such as the giant [[kauri]] and southern beech dominate the forests. It also has a [[list of birds of New Zealand|diverse range of birds]], several of which are flightless such as the [[kiwi]] (a national icon), the [[kakapo]], the [[takahē]] and the [[weka]],{{cite web|last1=Wilson|first1=Kerry-Jayne|title=Land birds – overview|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/land-birds-overview|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|date=24 September 2007|accessdate=16 August 2017}} and several species of [[penguin]]s.{{cite web|title=Penguins|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/native-animals/birds/birds-a-z/penguins/|website=www.doc.govt.nz|publisher=New Zealand Department of Conservation|accessdate=16 August 2017|language=en}} Around 30 bird species are currently listed as endangered or [[critically endangered]].{{cite web|title=New Zealand's threatened birds|url=http://www.doc.govt.nz/nature/conservation-status/threatened-birds/|website=www.doc.govt.nz|publisher=New Zealand Department of Conservation|accessdate=16 August 2017|language=en}} Conservationists recognised that threatened bird populations could be saved on offshore islands, where, once predators were exterminated, bird life flourished again. Many bird species, including the giant [[moa]], became extinct after the arrival of Polynesians, who brought dogs and rats, and Europeans, who introduced additional dog and rat species, as well as cats, pigs, ferrets, and weasels.{{cite web|last1=Holdaway|first1=Richard|title=Extinctions – New Zealand extinctions since human arrival|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/extinctions/page-4|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|language=en|date=24 September 2007|accessdate=16 August 2017}} Native flora and fauna continue to be hard-hit by [[invasive species]]. New Zealand conservationists have pioneered several methods to help threatened wildlife recover, including island sanctuaries, pest control, wildlife translocation, fostering, and ecological [[island restoration|restoration of islands]] and [[ecological island|other selected areas]].{{cite book|title=Handbook of ecological restoration: Principles of Restoration|chapter=Reptiles and Amphibians|first=Carl|last=Jones|page=362|editor1-first=Martin|editor1-last=Perrow|editor2-last= Davy|editor2-first= Anthony|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2002|isbn=0-521-79128-6|volume=2}} Massive [[Deforestation in New Zealand|deforestation]] occurred after humans arrived,{{cite web|last1=Swarbrick|first1=Nancy|title=Logging native forests'|url=https://www.teara.govt.nz/en/logging-native-forests|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=16 August 2017|date=24 September 2007}} with around half the forest cover lost to fire after Polynesian settlement.{{cite journal|author=McGlone, M.S. |year=1989 |url=http://nzes.org.nz/nzje/free_issues/NZJEcol12_s_115.pdf |title=The Polynesian settlement of New Zealand in relation to environmental and biotic changes |journal=New Zealand Journal of Ecology |volume=12(S) |pages=115–129 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140717220413/http://nzes.org.nz/nzje/free_issues/NZJEcol12_s_115.pdf |archivedate=17 July 2014 }} Much of the remaining forest fell after European settlement, being logged or cleared to make room for pastoral farming, leaving forest occupying only 23% of the land.Taylor, R. and Smith, I. (1997). [http://www.mfe.govt.nz/publications/ser/ser1997/index.html The state of New Zealand’s environment 1997]. Ministry for the Environment, Wellington. [[Pollution in New Zealand|Pollution]], particularly [[Water pollution in New Zealand|water pollution]], is one of New Zealand's most significant environmental issues. Fresh water quality is under pressure from agriculture, hydropower, urban development, pest invasions and climate change,{{cite web| url=http://www.pmcsa.org.nz/wp-content/uploads/PMCSA-Freshwater-Report.pdf| title=New Zealand's Fresh Waters| first=Sir Peter| last=Gluckman| date=12 April 2017| publisher=Prime Minister’s Chief Science Advisor}} although much of the country's household and industrial waste is now increasingly filtered and sometimes recycled. {{wideimage|Remarkables view MC.jpg|1000px|View from [[The Remarkables]] near [[Queenstown, New Zealand|Queenstown]], [[Otago]], South Island}} ===Protected areas=== {{main|Protected areas of New Zealand}} Some areas of land, the sea, rivers or lakes are protected by law, so their special plants, animals, landforms and other features are safe from harm. New Zealand has three [[List of World Heritage Sites in Oceania|World Heritage Sites]],{{cite web|title=New Zealand|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/NZ/|website=whc.unesco.org|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=23 August 2017|language=en}} 13 [[national parks of New Zealand|national parks]], 34 [[marine reserves of New Zealand|marine reserves]], and thousands of scenic, historic, recreation and other reserves.{{cite web|last1=Molloy|first1=Les|title=Protected areas|url=https://teara.govt.nz/en/protected-areas|publisher=Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand|accessdate=23 August 2017|date=September 2015}} The [[Department of Conservation (New Zealand)|Department of Conservation]] is responsible for managing 8.5 million [[hectares]] of public land (approximately 30% of New Zealand's landmass).{{cite web|title=New Zealand - Country Profile|url=https://www.cbd.int/countries/profile/default.shtml?country=nz|website=Convention on Biological Diversity|publisher=UN|accessdate=23 August 2017}} ===Environmental agreements=== New Zealand is party to several [[multilateral environmental agreement]]s.{{cite web|title=Multilateral environmental agreements|url=http://www.mfe.govt.nz/more/international-environmental-agreements/multilateral-environmental-agreements|website=www.mfe.govt.nz|publisher=Ministry for the Environment|accessdate=24 August 2017|language=en}} The major agreements are listed below. {{col-begin}} {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Antarctic-Environmental Protocol]] * [[Antarctic Treaty]] * [[Basel Convention]] * [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] * [[Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species]] * [[International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships]] * [[United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification]] * [[London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter|London Dumping Convention]] * [[Kyoto Protocol]] * [[Minamata Convention on Mercury]] * [[Environmental Modification Convention]] {{col-break|width=50%}} * [[Pacific Regional Environment Programme|Nouméa Convention]] * [[Ramsar Convention]] * [[Rotterdam Convention]] * [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]] * [[International Tropical Timber Agreement, 1994]] * [[Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants]] * [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] * [[Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer]] * [[Waigani Convention]] * [[International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling]] {{col-end}}
{{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category|Geography of New Zealand}} * [http://www.stats.govt.nz/ Statistics New Zealand] * [https://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/oceania/nz2.htm New Zealand] profile at World Atlas * [https://teara.govt.nz/en/natural-environment Natural Environment] – Te Ara Encyclopedia of New Zealand * [http://www.teara.govt.nz/1966/G/GeologyNewZealandsGeologicalHistory/Introduction/en New Zealand's Geological History] – 1966 Encyclopaedia of New Zealand {{CIA World Factbook}} {{New Zealand topics}} {{Geography of Oceania}} {{Portal bar|Geography|New Zealand}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of New Zealand}} [[Category:Geography of New Zealand| ]]

{{Infobox Former Country |native_name = Gobernación de Chiloé |conventional_long_name = |common_name = Chiloé |continent = South America |country = Chile |status = Colony |empire = Spain |religion = [[Roman Catholicism]] |era = [[Spanish Empire]] |life_span = 1600s–1784
1789–1826 |year_start = 1600s |year_end = 1826 |date_end = |event_start = |event_end = [[Treaty of Tantauco]] |p1 = Corregimiento of Chiloé |s1 = Conservative Republic | |flag = Cross of Burgundy |flag_type = Flag of the Spanish Empire |image_flag = Flag of New Spain.svg | |image_map = |image_map_caption = |flag_p1 = Flag of New Spain.svg |flag_s1 = Flag of Chile.svg |capital = [[Castro, Chile|Castro]] (until 1768)
[[Ancud]] (from 1768) |government_type = Monarchy |title_leader = [[List of Spanish monarchs|King]] |leader1 = [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III]] |year_leader1 = 1598–1621 |leader3 = [[Ferdinand VII of Spain|Ferdinand VII]] |year_leader3 = 1813–1826 |title_representative = [[Governor|Royal Governor]] |representative1 = [[Tomás de Olavarría]] |year_representative1 = 1600s–? |representative2 = [[Antonio de Quintanilla]] |year_representative2 = 1820–1826 |common_languages = [[Spanish language|Spanish]], [[Mapudungun]] |currency = [[Peso]]
[[Real de alerce]]}} The '''Governorate of Chiloé''' was political and military subdivision of the [[Spanish Empire]] that existed, with a [[Intendancy of Chiloé|1784–1789 interregnum]], from the 1600s to 1826. The Governorate of Chiloé depended on the [[Captaincy General of Chile]] until the late 18th century when it was made depend directly on the [[Viceroyalty of Peru]]. The administrative change was done simultaneously as the capital of the archipelago was moved from [[Castro, Chile|Castro]] to [[Ancud]] in 1768. The last Royal Governor of Chiloé, [[Antonio de Quintanilla]], depended directly on the central government in [[Madrid]]. ==Extent== The Governorate of Chiloé had its ''[[de jure]]'' northern limit a [[Bueno River]] in continental Chile. There the governorate limited with the territories of [[Valdivia]]. The area ''[[de facto]]'' controlled included the Chiloé Archipelago, the seashore forts and settlements north of [[Chacao Channel]] plus the [[Mission of Nahuel Huapi]] which was nevertheless financed from Valdivia.{{cite journal |last1=Urbina |first1=Ximena |last2= |first2= |year=2008 |title=The frustrated strategic mission of Nahuelhuapi, a point in Patagonia's inmensity |journal=[[Magallania]] |volume=36 |issue=1 |pages=5–30 |publisher= |doi= |url=http://www.scielo.cl/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0718-22442008000100001&lng=es&nrm=iso&tlng=es |accessdate=26 April 2013}} Historian [[Gabriel Guarda]] do however disagree claiming the Mission of Nahuel Huapi was within the jurisdiction of [[Valdivia]]. The so-called ''juncos of Osorno'' ([[Huilliche]]s) attempted in the late 18th century to have their lands, that lied just south of Bueno River, to be removed from the Governorate of Chiloé and incorporated to Valdivia. The reason of this was their bad relation and history of warfare with the settlements of around Chacao Channel. ==Royal governors== All 17th century Royal Governors were named by the [[Royal Governor of Chile]]. In the 18th century this system changed and while still named by the Royal Governor of Chile the position were to be ratified by the [[King of Spain]]. Later in the 18th century the [[Viceroy of Peru]] took over the duties of naming governors but still with the need of ratification by the King of Spain. Formally the office was granted based on merits during all of the 17th century. However, in the early 18th century "pecuniary service" begun also to be considered, which meant in practice that the office could be purchased. This practice was abolished in 1750. The office of Governor of Chiloé was commonly used to booster a carrier and then access more desirable positions of power in [[Central Chile]].{{cite journal |last=Urbina |first=Rodolfo |year=1990 |title=La rebelión indígena de 1712: los tributarios de Chiloé contra la encomienda |url=http://www.memoriachilena.cl/archivos2/pdfs/MC0008625.pdf |journal=Tiempo y espacio |volume= |issue=1 |pages=73–86 |location=Chillán |publisher=El Departamento |language=Spanish |format=pdf}} The position of Royal Governor of Chiloé dates to the early 17th century. Before that a succession of [[corregidor]]es existed including [[Alonso Benítez]] and [[Alonso de Góngora Marmolejo]]. Antonio Mejía who was sent by [[Alonso de Ribera]] to rule Chiloé died in a shipwreck in 1603 while approaching the archipelago. *[[Antonio Manríquez de Lara]] (1680s) *[[José Marín de Velasco]] (1708–1712, 1715–1719)Olguín, pp. 21–24 *Blas de Vera Ponce y León *[[Nicolás Salvo]] (1719–1723)Olguín, pp. 24–26 *[[Juan Dávila de Herzelles]] (1724–1728) *Fracisco José Sotomayor *Bartolomé Carrillo *Alonso Sánchez del Pozo *[[Francisco Gutiérrez de Espejo]] (1740–1741)Olguín, pp. 28–29 *[[Victoriano Martínez de Tineo]] (1743–1748)Olguín, pp. 29–31 *[[Antonio Narciso de Santa María]] (1749–1761)Olguín, pp. 31–34 *[[Juan Antonio Garretón]] (1761–1765)Olguín, pp. 34–37 *[[Manuel Fernández de Castelblanco]] (1765–1768)Olguín, pp. 37–38 *[[Carlos de Beranger Dusonet]] (1768–?)Olguín, pp. 38–39 *[[Antonio Martínez y La Espada]] The "notables" of Chiloé, represented by the local [[Cabildo (council)|cabildo]] had a conflictive relation with governor Martínez y La Espada. The cabildo made complaints to the authorities in [[Lima]].Olguín, pp. 39–41 Between 1784 and 1789 the position of governor was abolished and replaced by an [[intendant]]. The sole intendant of this period was [[Francisco Hurtado del Pino]].Urbina Burgos, R. (2012). [http://www.historiadelderecho.uchile.cl/index.php/RCHD/article/viewFile/25667/26998 Notas para el estudio del oficio de Gobernador de Chiloé durante el periodo indiano]. ''[[Revista Chilena de Historia del Derecho]]'', (10), pp. 205-219.Urbina Burgos, R. (1986). La Intendencia de Chiloé y los conflictos del gobernador-intendente Francisco Hurtado: 1784-1789. Revista de Historia y Geografía, 154. *[[Francisco Garos]] (1788–1789) *[[Pedro Cañaveral y Ponce]] (1789–1790 or 1791)Olguín, pp. 46–47 *[[Juan Antonio Montes de la Puente]] (1797–?) *[[Ignacio María Justiz y Urrutia]] *[[Antonio de Quintanilla]] (1820–1826) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} == Sources == *{{cite book |last=Olguín |first=Carlos |date=1971 |title=Instituciones Politicas Y Administrativas de Chiloe en El Siglo XVIII |url=https://books.google.cl/books?id=fZ0sS1-shAIC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=Antonio+Narciso+de+Santa+Mar%C3%ADa&source=bl&ots=M8cSGMuqYk&sig=J1gjoL5HKcn5sO7decGNaDEbbEU&hl=es&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi2xa2Hy_3KAhVEJpoKHaONDvoQ6AEIMjAG#v=onepage&q=Antonio%20Narciso%20de%20Santa%20Mar%C3%ADa&f=false |location=Santiago, Chile |publisher=Editorial Jurídica de Chile |pages= |isbn= |language=Spanish}} {{Chiloe Archipelago}} [[Category:Royal Governors of Chiloé| 01]] [[Category:History of Chiloé|.]] [[Category:Captaincy General of Chile]] [[Category:Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:17th century in Chile]] [[Category:18th century in Chile]] [[Category:18th century in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:19th century in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:17th-century establishments in Chile]] [[Category:1600s establishments in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:1780s disestablishments in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:1780s establishments in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:1820s disestablishments in the Viceroyalty of Peru]] [[Category:1820s disestablishments in the Spanish Empire]] [[Category:Lists of Spanish colonial governors and administrators|Chiloe]] [[Category:Chile-related lists|Chiloe]] [[Category:Chiloé Archipelago]] [[Category:16th-century Chilean people]] [[Category:17th-century Chilean people]] [[Category:18th-century Chilean people]]

revision.text:
'''Houtman''' or '''De Houtman''' is a [[Dutch language|Dutch]] surname. Translating as "(the) woodman", the origin of the name may be [[toponymic surname|toponymic]] ("from the woods") or [[occupational name|occupational]] (lumberman, carpenter, etc.).<ref>[http://www.cbgfamilienamen.nl/nfb/detail_naam.php?gba_naam=Houtman&nfd_naam=Houtman&info=varianten&operator=eq&taal= Houtman] at the Database of Surnames in The Netherlands.</ref> Notable people with the surname include:
*[[Cornelis de Houtman]] (1565–1599), Dutch explorer who discovered a new sea route from Europe to Indonesia *[[Frederick de Houtman]] (1571–1627), Dutch explorer who sailed along the Western coast of Australia to Batavia *{{illm|Jan Houtman|de||fy||nl|}} (1917–1944), Dutch resistance member murdered during World War II *[[Marques Houtman]] (born 1979), Cape Verdean American basketball point guard *[[Peter Houtman]] (born 1957), Dutch football striker *[[Rinus Houtman]] (born 1942), Dutch Reformed Political Party politician
==See also== *[[Houtman Abrolhos]], Wast Australian island chain named after Frederick de Houtman *[[10650 Houtman]], main-belt asteroid named after Cornelis de Houtman *[[Hautman]], surname
==References== {{reflist}}
{{surname|Houtman}}
[[Category:Dutch-language surnames]] [[Category:Occupational surnames]] [[Category:Toponymic surnames]]
