{{Infobox islands |name =Isla de la Convalecencia |native_name = |image_name =Pasig River, Ayala bridge, Hospicio de San Jose (Manila)(2018-02-05).jpg |image_caption=The island in the middle of [[Pasig River]] with Ayala Bridge in its foreground |area_m2 =594 |highest_mount= |elevation_m = |location = [[Pasig River]] |coordinates ={{coord|14|36|26|N|120|59|18|E|region:PH_type:isle|display=inline,title}} |archipelago = |country =Philippines | country_admin_divisions_title = City | country_admin_divisions = [[Manila]] | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = District | country_admin_divisions_1 = [[San Miguel, Manila|San Miguel]] | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = Barangay | country_admin_divisions_2 = Barangay 646, Zone 67 |population =500+ |density_km2 = 841.75 |ethnic_groups= }}
'''Isla de la Convalecencia''' ({{literal translation|Island of Convalescence}}), commonly known as simply '''Isla de Convalecencia''' (also spelled ''Isla de Convalescencia'' and sometimes erroneously called ''Isla de Convalencia''), is a small narrow [[river island]] in the [[Pasig River]] in [[Manila]], the Philippines. It is the only island dividing the Pasig River in Manila located between the districts of [[San Miguel, Manila|San Miguel]] on the north bank, and [[Ermita]] and [[Paco, Manila|Paco]] on the south. The island, best known as the location of the [[Hospicio de San Jose]], is administratively part of San Miguel's Barangay 646, Zone 67.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wikimapia.org/21108190/Barangay-646-Zone-67-San-Miguel-Manila |title=Barangay 646, Zone 67, San Miguel, Manila |publisher=[[Wikimapia]] |accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> It has a total area of approximately {{convert|594|sqm|sqft|sp=us}} and is connected to both sides of the river by the [[Ayala Bridge]].
Although the island is primarily occupied by the orphanage, it also hosts a detachment of the [[Philippine Coast Guard]] that patrols the periphery of the [[Malacañang Palace]] located just northeast of the island on the Pasig River.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/596168/coast-guard-deploy-more-personnel-near-bahay-pangarap?nomobile=1 |title=Coast Guard to deploy more personnel near Bahay Pangarap |publisher=[[Philippine Star]] |accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> It also houses a small community which includes the 412 children, 64 special needs and 120 elderly residents of the Hospicio de San Jose.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hospiciodesanjose.org/hospicio-in-todays-world |title=Hospicio in Today's World |publisher=[[Hospicio de San Jose]] |accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref>
==History== The island's name dates back to the 1830s when the ''Hospicio General'' was built and the island was used principally as a place of recuperation or [[convalescence]] for patients of the Hospital of San Juan de Dios.<ref name="hospicio">{{cite web|url=http://www.philippinestudies.net/ojs/index.php/ps/article/viewFile/1114/1727 |author=Camagay, Maria Luisa T. |title=The Hospicio de San Jose: Institutional Care for Mental Patients |publisher=[[Ateneo de Manila University]] |accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> It was earlier called '''Isla de San Andres''' (English: Saint Andrew's Island) in honor of Don Andres Blanco Vermudez who owned the island but who later donated it to the San Juan de Dios religious order.<ref name="hospicio"/> Prior to the construction of the orphanage and hospital, the island was the site of two Spanish fortifications known as Bastion de San Rafael and Bastion de San Andres.<ref name="diccionario">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vacNAvRQ-tcC&pg=PA237&lpg=PA237&dq=%22isla+de+convalecencia%22&source=bl&ots=CN0dxtK9LG&sig=ipwP-cF9FoQZe-a0ewBBQ9K96ng&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Np2CVIKXGuLImAWopoB4&ved=0CDUQ6AEwBQ |author=Buzeta, Manuel |title=Diccionario Geográfico, Estadístico, Histórico de las Islas Filipinas |publisher=Madrid: Imprenta de J.C. de la Peña |accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> The Bastion de San Rafael located on the island's eastern end had its main gate facing the river with a large wharf made of ''piedra de China'' (granite stones). This structure has since been replaced by the convent hospital built by the San Juan de Dios religious order.<ref name="diccionario"/> On the island's southern portion facing San Fernando de Dilao (now Paco) and Concepción (now part of Ermita) was the Bastion de San Andres. The Hospicio General was originally housed in an old ruined building called ''Petruz'' on the island's western portion. It had a small chapel, two infirmaries and several wards.<ref name="diccionario"/> It was later renamed to Hospicio de San Jose after [[Saint Joseph]], the orphanage's patron saint.<ref name="hospicio"/>
==See also== * [[List of islands in the Greater Manila Area]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Geography of Manila]] [[Category:Pasig River]] [[Category:San Miguel, Manila]] [[Category:River islands of the Philippines]] [[Category:Islands of Metro Manila]]

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{for|the U.S. diplomat|John Moors Cabot}} {{pp-move-indef}} {{pp-pc1}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = John Cabot
{{small|Giovanni Caboto}} | image = JohnCabotPainting.jpg | image_size = | occupation = [[List of maritime explorers|Maritime explorer]] | caption = John Cabot in traditional Venetian garb by Giustino Menescardi (1762). A mural painting in the Sala dello Scudo in the [[Doge's Palace, Venice|Palazzo Ducale]], Venice. | birth_date = c. 1450 | birth_place = [[Gaeta]], [[Kingdom of Naples]]{{cite web |title=Cabato |url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/caboto_(Dizionario-Biografico)/ |website=Treccani Italy |publisher=Treccani Italy}} | death_date = Between c. 1498 and 1501 | nationality = [[Italians|Italian]] | other_names = Giovanni Caboto, Zuan Chabotto, Giovanni Chabotte, Juan Caboto, Jean Caboto | spouse = Mattea (m. circa 1470) | children = Ludovico, [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastian]], and Sancto{{cite web |year=2007 |url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03126d.htm|title = ''Catholic Encyclopedia'' "John & Sebastian Cabot"|publisher = newadvent| accessdate = 17 May 2008 | last= |quote=}} | relatives = | known for = first European since the [[Norse colonization of North America]] to explore coastal parts of North America }} '''John Cabot''' ({{lang-it|Giovanni Caboto}}; c. 1450 – c. 1500) was an [[Italians|Italian]]{{cite book |last=Frederic C. |first= Lane|date=1978 |title=Storia di Venezia |language= Italian |location= Turin |publisher=Einaudi}} [[navigator]] and [[exploration|explorer]], born in the [[Kingdom of Naples]]. His 1497 discovery of the coast of [[North America]] under the commission of [[Henry VII of England]] was the first European exploration of coastal North America since the Norse visits to [[Vinland]] in the eleventh century. To mark the celebration of the 500th anniversary of Cabot's expedition, both the Canadian and British governments elected [[Cape Bonavista]], [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]], as representing Cabot's first landing site. However, alternative locations have also been proposed. ==Name and origins== Cabot is known today as ''Giovanni Caboto'' in Italian, as ''Zuan Chabotto'' in [[Venetian language|Venetian]], and as ''John Cabot'' in English. The non-Italian forms are derived from how his name was recorded in related 15th-century documents. In [[Republic of Venice|Venice]] he signed his names as "Zuan Chabotto", ''Zuan'' being a form of ''[[John (given name)|John]]'' typical to Venice.Edoardo Giuffrida, "New documents on Giovanni Caboto" in R. Mamoli Zorzi (ed.), ''Attraversare gli Oceani: Da Giovanni Caboto al Canada Multiculturale'' (Venice, 1999), 61. Juliana de Luna, [http://www.s-gabriel.org/names/juliana/16thcvenice.html Names from Sixteenth Century Venice] (2008). He continued to use this form in England, at least among Italians. He was referred to by his Italian banker in London as 'Giovanni Chabbote', in the only known contemporary document to use this version of his first name.[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot.html "Cabot Project"], Bristol Website He was born in Italy, the son of Giulio Caboto and his wife; he had a brother Piero. [[Gaeta]] (in the [[Province of Latina]]) and [[Castiglione Chiavarese]] (in the [[Province of Genoa]]) have both been proposed as birthplaces.{{cite DCB |title = Cabot, John |first= R.A. |last=Skelton |volume=1 |url = http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/cabot_john_1E.html}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.gianfrancobernabei.it/pdf/caboto.pdf|title=SCHEDA TECNICA DOCUMENTARIO "CABOTO": I CABOTO E IL NUOVO MONDO|language=Italian|format=PDF|access-date=3 June 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722034601/http://www.gianfrancobernabei.it/pdf/caboto.pdf|archive-date=22 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} (''TECHNICAL DOCUMENTARY "CABOTO": I and Catalan origins have been proved to be without foundation. The main evidence for Gaeta are records of a Caboto family residing there until the mid-15th century, but ceasing to be traceable after 1443.Roberto Almagiá, ''Commemorazione di Sebastiano Caboto nel IV centenario della morte'' (Venice, 1958), pp. 37–38. {{it}} [[Pedro de Ayala]], the Spanish envoy and Cabot's contemporary in London, described him in a letter to the Spanish Crown in 1498 as "another Genoese like Columbus".{{cite web|url=http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1498ayala.htm|title=Pedro de Ayala letter 1498 to the Spanish Crown|work=The Smugglers' City|publisher=Department of Historical Studies, University of Bristol|accessdate=20 February 2011}} John Cabot's son, [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastian]], said his father originally came from [[Genoa]]. In 1476 Cabot was made a citizen of the Republic of Venice, which required a minimum of fifteen years' residency in the city; thus he must have lived in Venice since at least 1461.J.A. Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages and Bristol Discovery Under Henry VII'' (Hakluyt Society, Second Series, No. 120, CUP, 1962), pp. 33–34. ==Early life== [[File:John Cabot house (Venice).jpg|thumb|Giovanni Caboto house in [[Venice]]]] He may have been born slightly earlier than 1450, which is the approximate date most commonly given for his birth. In 1471 Caboto was accepted into the religious [[confraternity]] of [[St John the Evangelist]]. Since this was one of the city's prestigious confraternities, his acceptance suggests that he was already a respected member of the community. Following his gaining full Venetian citizenship in 1476, Caboto would have been eligible to engage in maritime trade, including the trade to the eastern Mediterranean that was the source of much of Venice's wealth. He presumably entered this trade shortly thereafter. A 1483 document refers to his selling a slave in [[Crete]] whom he had acquired while in the territories of the Sultan of Egypt, which then comprised most of what is now [[Palestine (region)|Israel,]] [[Syria]] and [[Lebanon]].Giuffrida, "New documents on Giovanni Caboto" pp. 62–3 This is not sufficient to prove Cabot's later assertion that he had visited [[Mecca]], which he said in 1497 to the Milanese ambassador in London.[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1497soncino.htm Primary Sources: "Raimondo de Raimondi de Soncino, Milanese Ambassador in England, to Ludovico Maria Sforza, Duke of Milan, 18 December 1497], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol In this Mediterranean trade, he may have acquired better knowledge of the origins of the oriental (West Asian) merchandise he would have been dealing in (such as spices and silks) than most Europeans at that time. "Zuan Cabotto" (i.e. John Cabot) is mentioned in a variety of Venetian records of the 1480s. These indicate that by 1484 he was married to Mattea and already had at least two sons.Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 93, 192–95 Cabot's sons are Ludovico, [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastian]], and Sancto. The Venetian sources contain references to Cabot's being involved in house building in the city. He may have relied on this experience when seeking work later in Spain as a civil engineer.Giuffrida, "New documents on Giovanni Caboto," pp. 69 [[File:Cabot fugitive.png|thumb|Cabot's travels around Europe, 1488–95, following his escape from Venice]] Cabot appears to have got into financial trouble in the late 1480s and left Venice as an insolvent debtor by 5 November 1488. He moved to [[Valencia]], Spain, where his creditors attempted to have him arrested by sending a ''lettera di raccomandazione a giustizia'' ("a letter of recommendation to justice") to the authorities.M. F. Tiepolo, "Documenti Veneziani su Giovanni Caboto", ''Studi Veneziani'', xv (1973), pp. 585–97 While in Valencia, "John Cabot Montecalunya" (as he is referred to in local documents) proposed plans for improvements to the harbour. These proposals were rejected, however.M. Balesteros-Gaibrois, "Juan Caboto en España: nueva luz sobre un problema viejo", ''Revista de Indias'', iv (1943), 607–27 Early in 1494 he moved on to [[Seville]], where he proposed, was contracted to build and, for five months, worked on the construction of a stone bridge over the [[Guadalquivir]] river. This project was abandoned following a decision of the City Council on 24 December 1494.[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1494cabotseville.htm "John Cabot in Seville, 1494"], ''The Smugglers' City'', Dept. of History, University of Bristol After this Cabot appears to have sought support in Seville and [[Lisbon]] for an Atlantic expedition, before moving to London to seek funding and political support.Evan T. Jones and Margaret M. Condon, ''[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/cabot-and-bristols-age-of-discovery/ Cabot and Bristol's Age of Discovery: The Bristol Discovery Voyages 1480–1508]'' (University of Bristol, Nov. 2016), pp. 23–27. He probably reached England in mid-1495. ==Sponsorship== Like other explorers at those times, including [[Christopher Columbus]], Cabot led an expedition on commission, in his case, England. Cabot planned to depart to the west from a northerly latitude where the longitudes are much closer together, and where, as a result, the voyage would be much shorter.{{cite web|year=2007|title=The Cabot Dilemma: John Cabot's 1497 Voyage & the Limits of Historiography|publisher=[[University of Virginia]]|accessdate=9 April 2018|last=Derek Croxton|quote=|url=http://www.essaysinhistory.com/the-cabot-dilemma-john-cabots-1497-voyage-the-limits-of-historiography/|df=dmy-all}} He still had an expectation of finding an [[Northwest Passage|alternative route]] to China. Historians had thought that, on arrival in England, Cabot went to Bristol, a major maritime centre, to seek financial backers.[http://ehr.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/CXXI/492/778 Evan T. Jones, "The Matthew of Bristol and the financiers of John Cabot's 1497 voyage to North America", ''English Historical Review'' (2006)] This was the only English city to have had a history of undertaking exploratory expeditions into the Atlantic. Cabot's royal patent (issued by the Crown in 1496) stated that all expeditions should be undertaken from Bristol, so his primary financial supporters were probably based in that city. In any case, it also stipulated that the commerce resulting from any discoveries must be conducted with England alone.[https://www.questia.com/read/4414094/history-of-domestic-and-foreign-commerce-of-the-united The Commercial Policy of England Toward the American Colonies: the Acts of Trade], p. 38; in Emory R. Johnson, T. W. Van Metre, G. G. Huebner, D. S. Hanchett, ''History of Domestic and Foreign Commerce of the United State''s – Vol. 1, [[Carnegie Institution for Science|Carnegie Institution of Washington]], 1915 In the late 20th century, British historian [[Alwyn Ruddock]] claimed to have found documentation that Cabot went first to London, where he received some financial backing from its Italian community. She suggested one patron was Father Giovanni Antonio de Carbonariis, an [[Augustinian friar]] who was also the deputy to [[Adriano Castellesi]], the papal tax collector. Ruddock suggested that Carbonariis accompanied Cabot's 1498 expedition. She also suggested that the friar, on good terms with the King, introduced the explorer to [[Henry VII of England|King Henry VII]]. Beyond this, Ruddock claimed that Cabot received a loan from an Italian banking house in London. As Ruddock ordered the destruction of all her research notes on her death in 2005, scholars have had to duplicate her research and rediscover documents.Evan T. Jones, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119408885/HTMLSTART "Alwyn Ruddock: John Cabot and the Discovery of America"], ''Historical Research'' Vol 81, Issue 212 (2008), pp. 231–34. [http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot.html The Cabot Project] was formed at the University of Bristol in 2009 to research Cabot and the Bristol expeditions. Francesco Guidi Bruscoli ([[University of Florence]]) found some of Ruddock's documentation, confirming that Cabot received money in March 1496 from the [[Bardi family]] banking firm of Florence.{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1468-2281.2012.00597.x | volume=85 | title=John Cabot and his Italian financiers* | year=2012 | journal=Historical Research | pages=372–393 | last1 = Guidi-Bruscoli | first1 = Francesco}} The bankers located in London provided fifty ''nobles'' (£16 13s. 4d.) to support Cabot's expedition to "go and find the new land". This payment from the Florentine merchants would have represented a substantial contribution, although it was not enough to completely finance the expedition. On 5 March 1496 Henry VII gave Cabot and his three sons [[letters patent]] with the following charge for exploration: {{quote|text= ...free authority, faculty and power to sail to all parts, regions and coasts of the eastern, western and northern sea, under our banners, flags and ensigns, with five ships or vessels of whatsoever burden and quality they may be, and with so many and with such mariners and men as they may wish to take with them in the said ships, at their own proper costs and charges, to find, discover and investigate whatsoever islands, countries, regions or provinces of heathens and infidels, in whatsoever part of the world placed, which before this time were unknown to all Christians.}}[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1496cabotpatent.htm Primary Sources: "First Letters Patent granted by Henry VII to John Cabot, 5 March 1496"], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol Those who received such patents had the right to assign them to third parties for execution. His sons are believed to have still been minors.{{cite DCB|title=Cabot, Sebastian|first=R.A.|last=Skelton|volume=1|url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/cabot_sebastian_1E.html}} ==Expeditions== [[File:JohnCabotPlaqueDingleTowerHalifaxNovaScotia.jpg|thumb|John Cabot plaque: John Cabot departing [[Bristol]], [[England]] for [[Atlantic Canada]] (1497), installed at [[Sir Sandford Fleming Park]], [[Halifax, Nova Scotia]]]] Cabot went to [[Bristol]] to arrange preparations for his voyage. Bristol was the second-largest seaport in [[Kingdom of England|England]]. From 1480 onward it had supplied several expeditions to look for [[Brazil (mythical island)|Hy-Brazil]]. According to [[Celts|Celtic]] legend, this island lay somewhere in the Atlantic Ocean.Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 187–9 There was widespread belief among merchants in the port that Bristol men had discovered the island at an earlier date but then lost track of it. Ruddock had contended in a private 1988 letter to a colleague, Quinn, that she had found evidence in Italian archives that Bristol men had discovered North America pre-1470. As the island was believed to be a source of [[brazilwood]] (from which a valuable red dye could be obtained), merchants had economic incentive to find it.{{cite web|title=Salazar's account of Bristol's discovery of the Island of Brasil (pre 1476)|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1476brasil.htm|website=The Smuggler's City|publisher=University of Bristol}} ===First voyage=== Cabot's first voyage was little recorded. A winter 1497/98 letter from John Day (a Bristol merchant) to an addressee believed to be [[Christopher Columbus]] refers briefly to it, but writes mostly about the second, 1497 voyage. He notes, "Since your Lordship wants information relating to the first voyage, here is what happened: he went with one ship, his crew confused him, he was short of supplies and ran into bad weather, and he decided to turn back."[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1497johnday.htm "John Day letter to the Lord Grand Admiral, Winter 1497/8"], ''The Smugglers' City'', Dept. of History, University of Bristol. Since Cabot received his royal patent in March 1496, it is believed that he made his first voyage that summer. ===Second voyage=== Information about the 1497 voyage comes mostly from four short letters and an entry in a 1565 [[chronicle]] of the city of Bristol. The chronicle entry for 1496/7 says in full:
"This year, on St. John the Baptist's Day [24 June 1497], the land of America was found by the Merchants of Bristow in a shippe of Bristowe, called the Mathew; the which said the ship departed from the port of Bristowe, the second day of May, and came home again the 6th of August next following." – G.E. Weare, ''Cabot's Discovery of North America,'' (London, 1897), p. 116
What is known as the "John Day letter" provides considerable information about Cabot's second voyage. It was written during the winter of 1497/8 by Bristol merchant John Day (alias Hugh Say of London) to a man who is probably [[Christopher Columbus]]. Day is believed to have been familiar with the key figures of the expedition and thus able to report on it.{{cite web|title=The John Day Letter|url=http://www.heritage.nf.ca/articles/exploration/john-day.php|publisher=Heritage Newfoundland & Labrador|accessdate=13 September 2016}} If the lands Cabot had discovered lay west of the meridian laid down in the [[Treaty of Tordesillas]], or if he intended to sail further west, Columbus would probably have believed that these voyages challenged his monopoly rights for westward exploration.{{cite web|last1=Woodroffe|first1=Sasha|title=Breaking the Spanish Monopoly in the Caribbean|url=https://www.academia.edu/5128021/BREAKING_THE_SPANISH_MONOPOLY_IN_THE_CARIBBEAN|publisher=Academia|accessdate=13 September 2016}} In addition to these letters, [[Alwyn Ruddock]] claimed to have found another, written on 10 August 1497 by the London-based bankers of [[Fr. Giovanni Antonio de Carbonariis]]. This letter has yet to be found. From various written comments made by Ruddock, the letter did not appear to contain a detailed account of the voyage.[http://hdl.handle.net/1983/1274 E.T. Jones, "The Quinn papers: transcripts of correspondence relating to the Bristol discovery voyages to North America in the fifteenth century", p. 16.]. Note: Based on Ruddock's letter to Quinn on 1 May 1992, she thought that the bank was Venetian; Condon and Jones found documentation in August 2010 suggesting this conclusion was incorrect and that it was Florentine. Ruddock said the letter contained "new evidence supporting the claim that seamen of Bristol had already discovered land across the ocean before John Cabot's arrival in England."{{cite journal | last1 = Jones | first1 = Evan T. | year = | title = Alwyn Ruddock: ''John Cabot and the Discovery of America'' | url = http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119408885/HTMLSTART | journal = Historical Research | volume = 2007 | issue = | pages = 237–40 | doi=10.1111/j.1468-2281.2007.00422.x}} She contended that Bristol seamen had reached North America two decades before Cabot's expedition.[http://www.douglashunter.ca/douglashunter.ca/readings/Entries/2010/7/11_Rewriting_History__Alwyn_Ruddock_and_John_Cabot.html Douglas Hunter, "Rewriting History: Alwyn Ruddock and John Cabot"], extended July 2010 version of article by same name published in ''Canada's History'', April 2010; accessed 24 April 2015 [[File:Bonavista Cabot 2.jpg|thumb|A statue of John Cabot gazing across Bonavista Bay]] The known sources do not concur on all aspects of the events, and none can be assumed to be entirely reliable. Cabot was described as having one "little ship", of 50 tons burden, called the ''[[Matthew (ship)|Matthew]] of Bristol'' (according to the 1565 chronicle). It was said to be laden with sufficient supplies for "seven or eight months". The ship departed in May with a crew of 18 to 20 men. They included an unnamed Burgundian (modern- day Netherlands) and a Genoese barber, who presumably accompanied the expedition as the ship's surgeon. It is likely that two ranking Bristol merchants were part of the expedition. One was probably [[William Weston (explorer)|William Weston]], who had not been identified as part of Cabot's expedition before the find of a new document in the late 20th century. His participation was confirmed by a document found in the early 21st century noting his reward from the King in January 1498 after the ship returned. More importantly, in 2009 historian Evan Jones confirmed that Weston had undertaken an independent voyage to the New Found Land in 1499, probably under Cabot's patent, as the first Englishman to lead an expedition to North America.{{cite news|title=John Cabot was not Bristol's only explorer|url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/john-cabot-bristol-s-explorer/story-11239202-detail/story.html|accessdate=13 September 2016|work=Bristol Post|date=28 August 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150908095237/http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/John-Cabot-Bristol-s-explorer/story-11239202-detail/story.html|archivedate=8 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} Leaving Bristol, the expedition sailed past Ireland and across the Atlantic, making landfall somewhere on the coast of North America on 24 June 1497. The exact location of the landfall has long been disputed, with different communities vying for the honor. Historians have proposed [[Bonavista, Newfoundland|Cape Bonavista]] and [[St. John's, Newfoundland|St. John's]] (present-day [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]]); [[Cape Breton Island]] (Nova Scotia); as well as [[Labrador]] (Canada) and [[Maine]] (United States) as possibilities. Since the discovery of the "John Day letter" in the 1950s, it seems most likely that the initial landfall was either on Newfoundland or Cape Breton Island. This is because Day's letter implies that the coastline explored in 1497 lay between the latitudes of Bordeaux, France and Dursey Head in southern Ireland. The initial landfall seems to have taken place close to the southern latitude, with the expedition returning home after reaching the northern one.Evan T. Jones and Margaret M. Condon, ''[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/cabot-and-bristols-age-of-discovery/ Cabot and Bristol's Age of Discovery: The Bristol Discovery Voyages 1480–1508]'' (University of Bristol, 2016), pp. 43–44. [[File:1497 voyage.png|thumb|Route of 1497 voyage posited by Jones and Condon.]] For the 500th-anniversary celebrations, the governments of Canada and the United Kingdom designated [[Cape Bonavista]] in Newfoundland as the "official" landing place. Here in 1997 Queen Elizabeth II, along with members of the Italian and Canadian governments, greeted the replica ''Matthew'' of Bristol, following its celebratory crossing of the Atlantic.[[Republic of Venice|Lion of Saint Mark]], given by [[Regione Veneto]] to the city of [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], Nova Scotia, for the 500th year from the arrival of John Cabot: http://de.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Datei:Halifay_-_NS_-_Giovanni_Caboto_Gedenktafel.jpg&filetimestamp=20081107221453 Cabot is reported to have landed only once during the expedition and did not advance "beyond the shooting distance of a crossbow". Pasqualigo and Day both state that the expedition made no contact with any native people; crew found the remains of a fire, a human trail, nets and a wooden tool. The crew appeared to have remained on land just long enough to take on fresh water; they also raised the Venetian and Papal banners, claiming the land for the King of England and recognising the religious authority of the Roman Catholic Church.P. D'Epiro, M.D. Pinkowish, "Sprezzatura: 50 Ways Italian Genius Shaped the World" pp. 179–180 After this landing, Cabot spent some weeks "discovering the coast," with most "discovered after turning back." ===Final voyage=== [[File:Matthew-BristolHarbour-Aug2004.jpg|thumb|A replica of the ''[[Matthew (ship)|Matthew]]'' in [[Bristol]]]] On return to Bristol, Cabot rode to London to report to the King. On 10 August 1497, he was given a reward of £10 – equivalent to about two years' pay for an ordinary labourer or craftsman.Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', p. 214 The explorer was feted; Soncino wrote on 23 August that Cabot "is called the Great Admiral [note: as Christopher Columbus had been] and vast honour is paid to him and he goes dressed in silk, and these English run after him like mad". Such adulation was short-lived, for over the next few months the King's attention was occupied by the [[Second Cornish Uprising of 1497]], led by [[Perkin Warbeck]]. Once Henry's throne was secure, he gave more thought to Cabot. On 26 September, just a few days after the collapse of the revolt, the King made an award of £2 to Cabot.Evan T. Jones, 'Bristol, Cabot and the New Found Land, 1496–1500' in P.E. Pope and S. Lewis-Simpson (eds.), [https://boydellandbrewer.com/exploring-atlantic-transitions-hb.html ''Exploring Atlantic Transitions: Archaeologies of Permanence and Transience in New Found Lands''] (Boydell and Brewer, 2013), pp. 29–30. In December 1497 the explorer was awarded a pension of £20 per year. On February 3, 1498 he was given new letters patent covering the voyage[http://avalon.law.yale.edu/15th_century/cabot01.asp The Letters Patents of King Henry the Seventh Granted unto Iohn Cabot and his Three Sonnes, Lewis, Sebastian and Sancius for the Discouerie of New and Unknowen Lands], February 3, 1498 from [[Avalon Project]] and to help him prepare a second expedition.Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 217–19, 226–7 In March and April, the King also advanced a number of loans to Lancelot Thirkill of London, Thomas Bradley and John Cair, who were to accompany Cabot's new expedition.Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 214–15 The ''[[Great Chronicle of London]]'' (1189–1512) reports that Cabot departed with a fleet of five ships from Bristol at the beginning of May 1498, one of which had been prepared by the King. Some of the ships were said to be carrying merchandise, including cloth, caps, lace points and other "trifles".Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 220–23 This suggests that Cabot intended to engage in trade on this expedition. The Spanish envoy in London reported in July that one of the ships had been caught in a storm and been forced to land in Ireland, but that Cabot and the other four ships had continued on. For centuries no other records were found (or at least published) that relate to this expedition; it was long believed that Cabot and his fleet were lost at sea. But at least one of the men scheduled to accompany the expedition, Lancelot Thirkill of London, is recorded as living in London in 1501.Williamson (1962), ''The Cabot Voyages'', pp. 92–4 It is not known if Cabot died during the voyage, or returned safely and died shortly after.{{cite web|author=di Alberto Magnaghi |url=http://www.treccani.it/enciclopedia/giovanni-e-sebastiano-caboto_(Enciclopedia-Italiana)/ |title=CABOTO, Giovanni e Sebastiano in "Enciclopedia Italiana" |publisher=Treccani.it |date= |accessdate=2017-03-06}} [[File:La Cosa map North Atlantic (1500).png|thumb|Juan de La Cosa's map of the North Atlantic, 1500]] The historian [[Alwyn Ruddock]] worked on Cabot and his era for 35 years. She suggested that Cabot and his expedition successfully returned to England in the spring of 1500. She claimed their return followed an epic two-year exploration of the east coast of North America, south into the Chesapeake Bay area and perhaps as far as the Spanish territories in the Caribbean. Her evidence included the well-known world map of the Spanish cartographer [[Juan de la Cosa]]. His chart included the North American coast and seas 'discovered by the English' between 1497 and 1500.Evan T. Jones and Margaret M. Condon, ''[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/cabot-and-bristols-age-of-discovery/ Cabot and Bristol's Age of Discovery: The Bristol Discovery Voyages 1480–1508]'' (University of Bristol, Nov. 2016), p. 2. Ruddock suggested [[Fr. Giovanni Antonio de Carbonariis]] and the other friars who accompanied the 1498 expedition had stayed in Newfoundland and founded a mission. If Carbonariis founded a settlement in North America, it would have been the first Christian settlement on the continent, and may have included a church, the only medieval church to have been built there.Evan T. Jones (2008), [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119408885/HTMLSTART "Alwyn Ruddock: ''John Cabot and the Discovery of America'' "], first published online 5 April 2007, ''Historical Research'', Volume 81, Issue 212, May 2008, pp. 242–49. The Cabot Project at the [[University of Bristol]] was organized in 2009 to search for the evidence on which Ruddock's claims rest, as well as to undertake related studies of Cabot and his expeditions.[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot.html "The Cabot Project"], University of Bristol, 2009. The lead researchers on the project, Evan Jones and Margaret Condon, claim to have found further evidence to support aspects of Ruddock's case, including some of the information she intended to use to argue for a successful return of the 1498 expedition to Bristol. These appear to place John Cabot in London by May 1500, albeit Jones and Condon have yet to publish their documentation. The Project is collaborating on an archaeological excavation at the community of [[Carbonear]], Newfoundland, located at Conception Bay and believed the likely location for Carbonariis' mission settlement. The Archaeology of Historic Carbonear Project, carried out by [[Memorial University of Newfoundland]], has conducted summer fieldwork each season since 2011. So far, it has found evidence of planter habitation since the late 17th century and of trade with Spain through [[Bilbao]], including a Spanish coin minted in [[Peru]].[http://www.tcii.gov.nl.ca/pao/newsletters/pdf/Vol12-2013.pdf Peter E. Pope and Bryn Tapper, "Historic Carbonear, Summer 2013"], ''Provincial Archaeology Office 2013 Archaeology Review,'' Vol. 12-2013, pages 127-133, accessed 24 April 2015[http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2014-04-17/article-3692324/17th-century-coins-unearthed-in-Carbonear/ Mark Rendell, "17th-century coins unearthed in Carbonear"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20150424133701/http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2014-04-17/article-3692324/17th-century-coins-unearthed-in-Carbonear/ |date=24 April 2015 }}, ''The Telegram'', 17 April 2014, accessed 24 April 2015 ==Additional English voyages== Ruddock claimed that [[William Weston (explorer)|William Weston]] of Bristol, a supporter of Cabot, undertook an independent expedition to North America in 1499, sailing north from Newfoundland up to the [[Hudson Strait]]. If correct, this was probably the first [[North West Passage]] expedition. In 2009, Jones confirmed that William Weston (who was not previously known to have been involved) led an expedition from Bristol [with royal support] to the "[[Newfoundland|new found land]]" in 1499 or 1500, making him the first Englishman to lead exploration of North America. This find has changed the understanding of English roles in exploration of that continent.Evan T. Jones, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/122579649/HTMLSTART "Henry VII and the Bristol expeditions to North America: the Condon documents"], ''Historical Research'', 27 August 2009Evan T. Jones and M. M. Condon, "Weston, William (d. in or before 1505)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography,'' Oxford University Press, May 2010 King Henry VII continued to support exploration from Bristol. The king granted Hugh Eliot, Robert Thorne and his son a bounty of ₤20 in January 1502 for purchasing the ''Gabriel'', a ship for an expedition voyage that summer. Later in 1502 or early 1503 he paid Eliot a reward of ₤100 for a voyage, or voyages, in "2 ships to the Isle of new finding," as Newfoundland was called. This amount was larger than any previously accounted for in royal support of the explorations. ==Family== Cabot married Mattea around 1470, and had issue including three sons: * Ludovico Caboto * [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastiano Caboto]] * Santo Caboto ==Sebastian Cabot's voyages== {{main|Sebastian Cabot (explorer)}} [[Sebastian Cabot (explorer)|Sebastian Cabot]], one of John's sons, also became an explorer, later making at least one voyage to North America. In 1508 he was searching for the [[Northwest Passage]]. Nearly two decades later, he sailed to South America for Spain to repeat [[Ferdinand Magellan]]'s voyage around the world. He became diverted by searching for silver along the [[Río de la Plata]] (1525–8) in Argentina.{{cite book|last1=Cutler|first1=Miriam|title=Buenos Aires Street Guide|date=2011|publisher=LibrosEnRed|isbn=9781597546539|page=16|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=93hqjQsnoVcC&pg=PA16&lpg=PA16#v=onepage&q=Sebastian%20Cabot%20silver%20Argentina}} ==Legacy and honors== {{more citations needed|section|date=March 2018}} [[File:squarecabot.JPG|right|thumb|250px|''Square Cabot'', [[Montreal]]]] [[File:Newfoundland Cabots ship 1897 issue-10d.jpg|thumb|250px|
''~ The Matthew ~''
In 1897, on the 400th anniversary of Cabot's discovery of North America, the Newfoundland Post Office issued a commemorative stamp honouring Cabot and his discovery.]] * ''Giovanni Caboto'' (1762), painting at Ducal Palace, Venice.[[:File:JohnCabotPainting.jpg|Painting of Giovanni Caboto by Giustino Menescardi]] * [[Cabot Tower (Newfoundland)|Cabot Tower]] (1897) in [[St. John's, Newfoundland]], to commemorate the 400th anniversary of Cabot's voyage. * [[Cabot Tower (Bristol)|Cabot Tower]], in [[Bristol]], England. A 30-metre tall red sandstone tower begun in 1897 to mark the 400th anniversary. * Denis William Eden painting: ''John Cabot and his sons receive the charter from Henry VII to sail in search of new lands'' (1910), at Houses of Parliament.[http://www.parliament.uk/worksofart/artwork/denis-william-eden/john-cabot-and-his-sons-receive-the-charter-from-henry-vii-to-sail-in-search-of-new-lands-1496/2594 Denis William Eden: ''John Cabot and his sons receive the charter from Henry VII to sail in search of new lands''] (1910), at Houses of Parliament * Giovanni Caboto Club (est. 1925), an Italian club located in Windsor, Ontario.[http://www.cabotoclub.com/history.html Giovanni Caboto Club History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817001046/http://www.cabotoclub.com/history.html |date=17 August 2009 }} * A 1952 statue of the explorer is at [[Council House, Bristol|Bristol's Council House]].Douglas Merritt, ''Sculpture in Bristol'' (Bristol, 2002), p. 90. Note: In 1956 this was designated as a "symbolic figure of an Elizabethan seaman," although the sculptor [[Charles Wheeler (sculptor)|Charles Wheeler]] exhibited the work in the Royal Academy Summer Exhibition of 1952 as "Number 1423, John Cabot – sketch model for the statue on the New Council House, Bristol". The figure is dressed in fifteenth-century clothing, has a fifteenth-century navigational instrument (astrolabe) hanging from his belt and holds what appear to represent Cabot's [[letters patent]]. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/bolou/3743246797/ Photograph: Statue of John Cabot / Elizabethan Seaman] * [[John Cabot University]] is a United States-affiliated university established in 1972 in Rome, Italy. * A 1985 [[commons:File:Bristol.john.cabot.500pix.jpg|bronze statue]] of the explorer by Stephen Joyce, is located at [[Bristol Harbour]]side. * A replica of the [[Matthew (ship)|''Matthew'' of Bristol]] built to commemorate the 500th anniversary of the 1497 voyage, docked in Bristol. * A second replica of the [[Matthew (ship)|''Matthew'']] is located at [[Cape Bonavista]]. * The scenic [[Cabot Trail]] in the [[Cape Breton Highlands]] is named after the explorer. * [[John Cabot Academy]] is an independent school in Bristol, England. * Cabot Links – a golf course in Inverness, Nova Scotia. * [[Cabot, Bristol|Cabot Ward]] is an electoral district in Bristol, indirectly named for the explorer and directly after the local [[Cabot Tower (Bristol)|Cabot Tower]]. * [[Cabot Square]]s in London and [[Cabot Square, Montreal|Montreal]]. * [[Cabot Circus]], a 2008 shopping mall in Bristol, named as a result of a citywide poll. * John Cabot Road in north [[Phoenix, Arizona]]. * Cabot Street in [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador]]. * A bronze statue of the explorer stands at the [[Confederation Building (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Confederation Building]], St. John's. * A bronze statue of the explorer is located at [[Cape Bonavista]], Newfoundland. Plaques in English, French and Italian commemorate the historic voyage. * John Cabot Catholic Secondary School in Mississauga, Canada is named after the explorer * Giovanni Caboto park located in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada.. ==See also== *[[List of people who disappeared mysteriously]] ==Sources== * Evan T. Jones and Margaret M. Condon, ''[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/cabot-and-bristols-age-of-discovery/ Cabot and Bristol's Age of Discovery: The Bristol Discovery Voyages 1480–1508]'' (University of Bristol, Nov. 2016). This short book provides an up-to-date account of the voyages, based on the research of the "[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/ Cabot Project]", aimed at a general audience. * Evan T. Jones, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/119408885/HTMLSTART "Alwyn Ruddock: 'John Cabot and the Discovery of America' "], ''Historical Research'' Vol 81, Issue 212 (2008), pp. 224–254. Provides updated information on new discoveries of documents related to Cabot and his voyage, and claims made in the late 20th century by Alwyn Ruddock. * Evan T. Jones, [http://www3.interscience.wiley.com/cgi-bin/fulltext/122579649/HTMLSTART "Henry VII and the Bristol expeditions to North America: the Condon documents"], ''Historical Research'', 27 Aug 2009, relates primarily to newly discovered documents related to William Weston's 1499 voyage. * Francesco Guidi-Bruscoli, [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-2281.2012.00597.x/full 'John Cabot and his Italian Financiers'], ''Historical Research'' (Published online, April 2012). * J.A. Williamson, ''The Cabot Voyages and Bristol Discovery Under Henry VII'' (Hakluyt Society, Second Series, No. 120, CUP, 1962). Considered the essential source-book for Cabot and his voyages. Numerous documents have been discovered in the Italian, Spanish and English archives that provide new insights into these events and era. * {{cite DCB |title=Cabot, John |first=R. A. |last=Skelton |url=http://www.biographi.ca/en/bio/cabot_john_1E.html}} A short introduction; it has been updated based on material published related to The Cabot Project at the University of Bristol. * H.P. Biggar (ed.), ''The Precursors of Jacques Cartier, 1497–1534: A Collection of Documents Relating to the Early History of the Dominion of Canada'' (Ottawa, 1911). Contains transcriptions of many of the original documents in their original languages – i.e. Latin, Spanish and Italian. * P. D'Epiro, M.D. Pinkowish, ''Sprezzatura: 50 Ways Italian Genius Shaped the World,'' 1st Anchor Book Edition, 2001, pp. 179–180. ==Further reading== *Evan T. Jones and Margaret M. Condon, ''[http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot/cabot-and-bristols-age-of-discovery/ Cabot and Bristol's Age of Discovery: The Bristol Discovery Voyages 1480–1508]'' (University of Bristol, Nov. 2016). *[https://books.google.com/books?id=jI5uh4SknFoC&pg=PT5&source=gbs_selected_pages#v=onepage&q=%27%27The%20Race%20to%20the%20New%20World%3A%20Christopher%20Columbus%2C%20John%20Cabot%2C%20and%20a%20Lost%20History%20of%20Discovery%27%27 Douglas Hunter, ''The Race to the New World: Christopher Columbus, John Cabot, and a Lost History of Discovery''] (New York: Macmillan, 2011). He uses findings from The Cabot Project of the University of Bristol as part of his research. This is described by archeologist Peter Pope as "the first substantial book on Cabot since the batch that observed the quincentennial of 1997 and the most detailed comparison to date of the careers of Columbus and Cabot."[https://muse.jhu.edu//journals/canadian_historical_review/v093/93.4.pope.html Peter Pope, "Review: ''The Race to the New World: Christopher Columbus, John Cabot, and a Lost History of Discovery.'' Douglas Hunter"], ''The Canadian Historical Review'', Vol.93, No.4, December 2012 {{subscription required|via Project MUSE}} *Maura, Juan Francisco. ''El mito de "John Cabot": construcción británica para reclamar la soberanía de Norteamérica''. Cuadernos Hispanoamericanos. 788 (2016): 4–25. (Available on line:http://www.aecid.es/Centro-Documentacion/Documentos/Publicaciones%20AECID/WEB_CHA_788_2016.pdf). ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Giovanni Caboto|John Cabot}} * [http://www.nfb.ca/film/john_cabot_a_man_of_the_renaissance ''John Cabot: A Man of the Renaissance''], National Film Board of Canada *[http://www.historicacanada.ca/content/heritage-minutes/john-cabot?media_type=41& John Cabot], Historica Canada * [http://www.bristol.ac.uk/history/research/cabot.html The Cabot Project], research project at [[University of Bristol]], led by [http://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/person/Evan.Jones Dr Evan Jones]. * [http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/03126d.htm O. Hartig, "John and Sebastian Cabot"], ''The Catholic Encyclopedia'' (New Advent, 1908). ''Very'' dated. ===Primary sources=== *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1476brasil.htm Introduction and Source: "Salazar's account of Bristol's discovery of the Island of Brasil (pre 1476)"], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1496cabotpatent.htm Sources: "First Letters Patent granted by Henry VII to John Cabot, 5 March 1496"], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1497pasqualigo.htm Primary Sources: "Lorenzo Pasqualigo to his brothers at Venice, 23 August 1497"], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1497soncino.htm Primary Sources: "Raimondo de Raimondi de Soncino, Milanese Ambassador in England, to Ludovico Maria Sforza, Duke of Milan, 18 December 1497], ''The Smugglers' City'', History Dept., University of Bristol *[http://www.bris.ac.uk/Depts/History/Maritime/Sources/1497milanletter.htm Primary Source: Letter, author unknown: "News sent from London to the Duke of Milan, 24 August 1497"], ''The Smugglers' City'', Dept. of History, University of Bristol, briefly notes Cabot's voyage {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cabot, John}} [[Category:1450s births]] [[Category:1500s deaths]] [[Category:1490s missing person cases]] [[Category:15th-century Venetian people]] [[Category:Age of Discovery]] [[Category:Explorers of Canada]] [[Category:Explorers from the Republic of Venice]] [[Category:Italian explorers of North America]] [[Category:Italian navigators]] [[Category:Slave traders]] [[Category:History of Bristol]] [[Category:Italian emigrants to the Kingdom of England]] [[Category:People from Chioggia]] [[Category:People of the Tudor period]] [[Category:Persons of National Historic Significance (Canada)]]

revision.text:
'''Julius Honorius''', also known as '''Julius Orator''', a teacher of geography during [[Late Antiquity]].
He is known only by a single work, ''Cosmographia'', which is a set of notes he had written down by one of his students while he lectured about a world map (''sphaera''), and by references to this work by later writers such as [[Cassiodorus]]. The importance of the ''Cosmographia'' is that it is one of very few geographical works of this period in which any reliance can be placed. A number of variant manuscripts exist, which have been studied by Nicolet & Gautier Dalché. The only (relatively) modern print version was as one of a collection of fragmentary texts published by Riese.<ref>See bibliography. Riese's work employs a very complex annotation system to bring together for comparison manuscripts which may differ very significantly.</ref>
Nothing else is known of his life, and even the date of the ''Cosmographia'' is not known with certainty. The reference by [[Cassiodorus]]<ref>''Institutiones divinarum et saecularium litterarum'', 25.</ref> puts it prior to the mid 6th century. The most recent study, by [[Yves Modéran|Modéran]], suggests a late 4th century date.<ref>[[Yves Modéran]], ''Les Maures et l'Afrique Romaine (IVe-VIIe siècle)'', Ecole Française de Rome, 2003, pp. 85-93 ({{ISBN|2-7283-0640-0}}).</ref>
An attempt to reconstruct the ''sphaera'' was made by Kubitschek.<ref>W. Kubitschek, "Die Erdtafel des Julius Honorius", ''Wiener Studien'' v. 7 (1885) 1-24 & 278-310</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Bibliography == *Nicolet, C. & Gautier Dalché, P. "Les quatre sages de Jules César et la mesure du monde selon Julius Honorius", ''Journal des Savants'' Oct.-Dec. 1986, 157-218. *Riese, A. 1878. ''Geographi latini minores collegit, recensuit, prolegomenis instruxit''. Henninger Bros, Heilbronn.
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Latin-language writers|Geographers]] [[Category:Ancient Roman writers|Geographers]] [[Category:Ancient geographers|Roman]] [[Category:Classical geography]]

'''Leaf mold''' ('''Leaf mould''' outside of the United States) is the product of slow decomposition of deciduous [[shrub]] and [[tree]] leaves. It is a form of [[compost]] produced primarily by fungal breakdown.<ref>[http://compost.css.cornell.edu/microorg.html Compost organisms]</ref>
==Description== Leaves shed in autumn tend to have a very low nitrogen content and are often dry. Their main constituents are [[cellulose]] and [[lignin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://compost.css.cornell.edu/chemistry.html|title= Compost Chemistry|publisher= Cornell University|access-date=6 October 2016}}</ref> Because of this, autumn leaves break down far more slowly than most other compost ingredients with very little bacterial decomposition involved.
==Time and process== Fungal decomposition of a heap of leaves in the open can take between one and two years to break down into a dark brown fine powdery [[humus|humic]] matter. During the two to three years that the process takes to complete in damp temperate climates, a succession of different fungal species may be involved.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/ismej/journal/v7/n3/full/ismej2012116a.html|title=Fungal community on decomposing leaf litter undergoes rapid successional changes|author1=Jana Voříšková1|author2=Petr Baldrian|journal=The ISME Journal|access-date=7 October 2016|date= 11 October 2012|volume=7|issue=3|doi=10.1038/ismej.2012.116|pages=477–486|pmc=3578564}}</ref> A range of micro fauna are also involved in converting the leaf material into a fine-grained humus, including many [[isopods]], [[millipede]]s, [[earthworms]], etc.
==Uses== In the natural environment the slow decomposition of leaves provides a moist growing medium for young plants and also protects the ground from drying out during periods of low rainfall. It is a significant component of [[soil organic matter]], particularly in temperate deciduous woodland. The slow rate of decomposition allows the plant nutrients bound up in the leaves to be released slowly back into the environment where they can be re-used by plants. Autumn leaves are often collected as part of gardening or farming and kept in pits or containers so that the leaf mold can be used in the garden. The presence of oxygen from the air and sufficient moisture are essential for leaf decomposition. Leaf mold is not high in nutrient content, but it is excellent humic [[soil conditioner]] because of its ability to retain moisture and provide a good growing medium for seedling roots. Leaves collected off roads and pavements may be contaminated by pollutants which can become more concentrated as the leaves decompose into a smaller volume <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/291575/LIT_8942_4547cc.pdf|publisher=The Environment Agency|access-date=6 October 2016|title=Leaf litter in street sweepings: investigation into collection and treatment}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Worm compost]] *[[Spent mushroom compost]] *[[Recycling]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *BBC Gardening: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/gardening/basics/techniques/soil_makeleafmould1.shtml How to Make Leaf Mould] *[http://www.greenfingers.com/articledisplay.asp?id=347 How to Make Leaf Mould] - Greenfingers.com
{{Permaculture}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Leaf Mold}} [[Category:Composting]] [[Category:Soil improvers]] [[Category:Permaculture]] [[Category:Sustainable gardening]] [[Category:Sustainable products]] [[Category:Soil]] [[Category:Leaves]]
[[ja:腐葉土]]

{{Commons category|Flags of Venezuela}} The following is a '''list of [[Flag of Venezuela|flags of]] [[Venezuela]]'''. ==National flags == {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (state).svg|border|100px]] || 2006–present || [[State flag|State]] and [[war flag]], [[State ensign|state]] and [[naval ensign]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red with the [[Coat of arms of Venezuela|coat of arms]] on the hoist side of the yellow band and an arc of eight white five-pointed stars centered in the blue band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela.svg|border|100px]] || 2006–present || [[Civil flag]] and [[Civil ensign|ensign]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red with an arc of eight white five-pointed stars centered in the blue band. Ratio 2:3. |} ===Historical flags=== {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|border|100px]] || 1506–1717
({{small|211 years}}) || [[Cross of Burgundy]], military flag of Spain used as banner of its overseas territories. || Cross of Burgundy on a white field. |- | [[File:Bandera de Costas.svg|border|100px]] || 1717–1785
({{small|68 years}}) || Military banner of Spain used by the [[Viceroyalty of New Granada]]. || Coat of arms of Spain on a white field. |- | [[File:Flag of Spain (1785-1873 and 1875-1931).svg|border|100px]] || 1785–1819
({{small|34 years}}) || War flag of Spain, used by the [[Captaincy General of Venezuela]] || [[Spanish fess]] of red, gold and red with the lesser arms of Spain towards the hoist-side of the flag. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1811).svg|border|100px]] || 1811–1811
({{small|11 months, 11 days}}) || Flag of the [[First Republic of Venezuela|First Venezuelan Republic]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red in which the yellow band takes half of the flag; with a canton on the hoist side showing an [[Indigenous peoples of Venezuela|indigenous woman]], an [[Orinoco crocodile]] and the [[Caribbean Sea]]. |- | [[File:Bandera de la Guerra a Muerte.svg|border|100px]] || 1813–1814
({{small|1 year, 1 month}}) || Flag of the [[Second Republic of Venezuela|Second Venezuelan Republic]]. Commonly known as the "''Bandera de Guerra a Muerte''" ("flag of the [[Guerra a muerte|War to the Death]]") || Red field with a white rhombus encasing a black rectangle. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1817 and 1859).svg|border|100px]] || 1817
({{small|6 months, 8 days}}) || Flag of the [[Third Republic of Venezuela|Third Venezuelan Republic]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red with seven blue stars on the yellow band. |- | [[File:Bandera de Angostura (20 de noviembre de 1817).svg|border|100px]] || 1817–1819
({{small|1 year, 11 months, 27 days}}) || Flag of the [[Third Republic of Venezuela|Third Venezuelan Republic]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red with eight blue stars on the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of the Gran Colombia (1819-1820).svg|border|100px]] || 1819–1820
({{small|24 days}}) || First flag of [[Gran Colombia]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red in which the yellow band takes half of the flag, with the coat of arms of the Republic of Colombia on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of the Gran Colombia (1820-1821).svg|border|100px]] || 1820–1821
({{small|1 year, 8 months, 27 days}}) || Second flag of [[Gran Colombia]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red in which the yellow band takes half of the flag, with the coat of arms of the Republic of Colombia on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of the Gran Colombia.svg|border|100px]] || 1821–1830
({{small|9 years, 8 days}}) || Third flag of [[Gran Colombia]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with the coat of arms of the Republic of Colombia in the center. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1830-1836).svg|border|100px]] || 1830–1836
({{small|5 years, 6 months, 6 days}}) || Provisional flag of the [[History of Venezuela (1830–1908)|State of Venezuela]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with the coat of arms of the State of Venezuela in the center. |- | [[File:Bandera de Venezuela 1836-1859.svg|border|100px]] || 1836–1859
({{small|27 years, 3 months 9 days}}) || Flag of the [[History of Venezuela (1830–1908)|State of Venezuela]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with the coat of arms of the State of Venezuela on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1817 and 1859).svg|border|100px]] || 1859
({{small|3 months, 20 days}}) || First flag of the Federation || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with seven blue stars on the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1859-1863).svg|border|100px]] || 1859–1863
({{small|4 years, 1 month, 14 days}}) || Second flag of the Federation || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with the coat of arms of the State of Venezuela in the center. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1863–1905).svg|border|100px]] || 1863–1905
({{small|41 years, 7 months, 30 days}}) || Flag of the [[United States of Venezuela]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with seven white stars arranged in a hexagon in the center of the blue band. |- | [[File:State flag of Venezuela (1863-1905).svg|border|100px]] || 1863–1905
({{small|41 years, 7 months, 30 days}}) || State flag of the [[United States of Venezuela]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with an arc of seven white stars in the center of the blue band and the country's coat of arms on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1905–1930).svg|border|100px]] || 1905–1930
({{small|25 years, 3 months, 18 days}}) || Flag of the [[United States of Venezuela]] under [[Juan Vicente Gómez]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with a circle of seven white stars in the center of the blue band. |- | [[File:State flag of Venezuela (1905-1930).svg|border|100px]] || 1905–1930
({{small|25 years, 3 months, 18 days}}) || State flag of the [[United States of Venezuela]] under [[Juan Vicente Gómez]] || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with an arc of seven white stars in the center of the blue band and the country's coat of arms on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1930–1954).svg|border|100px]] || 1930–1954Applied until 2006 as the civil flag
({{small|23 years, 7 months, 2 days}}) || Flag of the Republic of Venezuela || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with an arc of seven white stars in the center of the blue band. |- | [[File:State flag of Venezuela (1930-1954).svg|border|100px]] || 1930–1954
({{small|23 years, 7 months, 2 days}}) || State flag of the Republic of Venezuela || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with an arc of seven white stars in the center of the blue band and the country's coat of arms on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- | [[File:Flag of Venezuela (1954–2006).svg|border|100px]] || 1954–2006Only applied to the state flag
({{small|51 years, 18 days}})
2006–presentThe flag is used by some opposition parties. || Flag of the Republic of Venezuela (1954–1999)
Flag of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela (1999–2006) || Horizontal tricolor of yellow, blue and red, with an arc of seven white stars in the center of the blue band and the country's coat of arms on the hoist side of the yellow band. |- |} ==Governmental flags== {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Presidential Standard of Venezuela.svg|border|100px]] || 2006–present || [[Presidential standard]] || Square yellow field with the coat of arms in the center. |- | [[File:Presidential Standard of Venezuela (1997-2006).svg|border|100px]] || 1997–2006 || [[Presidential standard]] || Square yellow field with the coat of arms in the center. |- | [[File:Presidential Standard of Venezuela (1970-1997).svg|border|100px]] || 1970–1997 || [[Presidential standard]] || Square red field with the coat of arms in the center. |- | [[File:Presidential Standard of Venezuela(at Sea).svg|border|100px]] || 2006–present || [[Presidential standard]] (at sea) || Blue field with the coat of arms in the center and four white stars in each corner. Ratio 2:3. |} ==Military flags== {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Estandarte Comandante Supremo.svg|102px]] || 2014–present || Supreme Commander's Honorary Colour || Used in all military ceremonies |- | [[File:Flag of the Venezuelan Ministry of Defense.png|border|100px]] || 1951–2007 || Defense ministry flag || |- | [[File:Flag of the National Army of Venezuela.svg|102px]] || 1999–present || Army flag || A blue field with a red diagonal band with the coat of arms of the Army from the upper hoist side to the lower fly side. |- | [[File:Flag of the Venezuelan Navy.png|border|100px]] || 1999–present || Navy flag || |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Venezuela 1930–2006.svg|border|100px]] || 1930–2006 || Former naval jack || |- | [[File:Naval Jack of Venezuela.svg|border|100px]] || 2006–present || [[Naval jack]] || Blue field with a white anchor under an arc of eight white stars. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of the Venezuelan Air Force.png|border|100px]] || 1995–present || Air force flag || |- | [[File:Flag of the Venezuelan National Guard.png|border|100px]] || 1999–present || National guard flag || |} ==States, dependencies and Capital District== {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Amazonas State.svg|100px|border]] | 2002–present | [[Amazonas, Venezuela|Amazonas]] | Horizontal tricolor of blue, green and red with a brown outline of the state (bordered in yellow) in the center. The map is charged with seven stars spread unevenly inside the map, showing the location of the state's seven municipalities, alongside an outline of [[Cerro Autana]] and a [[Yanomami people|Yanomami]]'s face. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Anzoátegui State.svg|100px|border]] | 1999–present | [[Anzoátegui]] | Horizontal tricolor of blue, yellow and green with a black border outlining the state in the center and the state's coat of arms on the hoist side of the blue band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Apure State.svg|100px|border]] | 1996–present | [[Apure]] | Horizontal triband of yellow, blue and green; with a white triangle based at the hoist side charged with the state's coat of arms and seven white stars on the blue band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Aragua State.svg|100px|border]] | 1930–present | [[Aragua]] | Bicolor diagonal quartered of red and yellow with the state's coat of arms in the center. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Barinas State.svg|100px|border]] | 1958–present | [[Barinas (state)|Barinas]] | Horizontal tricolor of blue, white and green, with a red rectangle in the center of the white band, charged with a yellow rising sun, a road of the same color and a green palm tree. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Bolívar State.svg|100px|border]] | 1930–present | [[Bolívar (state)|Bolívar]] | Yellow field with a green circle in the center, superposed by three horizontal blue stripes. The state's coat of arms is on the upper hoist side of the yellow field and the central blue stripe is charged with eight white stars. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Carabobo State.svg|100px|border]] | 1995–present | [[Carabobo]] | Horizontal triband of red, blue and red again, in which the upper red band takes three fifths of the flag. The red band is charged with a yellow sun based on the fly side of the blue band. The sun is charged with the Arc of Carabobo. The upper side of the blue band is bordered by a green line. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Caracas.svg|100px|border]] | ?–present | [[Capital District (Venezuela)|Capital District]] {{small|([[Caracas]])}} | Red field with the coat of arms of [[Caracas]] in the center. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Cojedes State.svg|100px|border]] | 1997–present | [[Cojedes (state)|Cojedes]] | Horizontal triband of orange, black and blue in which the orange band takes four sixths of the flag; with a blue circle charged with a yellow sun on the hoist side of the orange band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Delta Amacuro State.svg|100px|border]] | 2002–present | [[Delta Amacuro]] | Horizontal triband of light blue, green and blue; with a white, yellow, brown and black-edged blue triangle based on the hoist, charged with a gold-edged green outline of the state. The proportion of the bands is 3:2:3; and the sky blue band is charged with an arc of four white stars. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Federal dependencies of Venezuela's Flag.svg|100px|border]] | ?–present | [[Federal Dependencies of Venezuela|Federal Dependencies]] | Horizontal tricolor of green, white and blue, with a red fish in the center of the white band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Falcón.svg|100px|border]] | 2006–present | [[Falcón (state)|Falcón]] | Blue field with a yellow rising sun on the upper hoist side and a white moon on the lower fly side; charged with a red chief bearing the words "''Muera la Tiranía y Viva la Libertad''" ("Death to Tyranny and long live Freedom"). Based on [[Francisco de Miranda]]'s naval flag. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag_of_Gu%C3%A1rico.svg|100px|border]] | 1995–present | [[Guárico]] | Four horizontal bands of blue, white, yellow and green, with the state's coat of arms on the hoist side of the blue band; charged with a half-blue, half-green outline of the map bearing a cow's head sided by an ear of rice and an ear of sorghum, and an image of the ''Morros de San Juan''. The map is surrounded by fourteen golden stars (seven on each side). Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Lara State.svg|100px|border]] | 2000–present | [[Lara (state)|Lara]] | Two horizontal bands of red and green, the red twice the size of the green. The red band is charged with a setting sun with thirteen yellow-edged white rays based on the green band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Mérida State.svg|100px|border]] | 1996–present | [[Mérida (state)|Mérida]] | Three triangles of green, white and light blue, with a red star in the center. The white central triangle is based on the bottom of the flag, dividing the green and light blue triangles. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Miranda state.svg|100px|border]] | 2006–present | [[Miranda (state)|Miranda]] | Horizontal tricolor of black, red and yellow, with an arc of six white stars in the center of the red band and a yellow sun on the hoist side of the black band, charged with two cocoa branches and the words "''Libertad o Muerte''" ("Liberty or Death"). Based on [[Francisco de Miranda]]'s military flag. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Monagas State.png|100px|border]] | ?–present | [[Monagas (state)|Monagas]] | Light blue field superposed by three horizontal bands of blue, green and black, with a yellow sun based on the lower side of the green band. The light blue field is charged with a stylized black outline of [[Juana Ramírez]] under an arc of thirteen white stars Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Nueva Esparta.svg|100px|border]] | 1998–present | [[Nueva Esparta]] | Horizontal tricolor of yellow, green and blue, in which the yellow band takes half of the flag; the green band is charged with three white stars and the yellow band is charged with a white semi-circle based on the fly side of the green band. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Portuguesa.svg|100px|border]] | 1952–present | [[Portuguesa (state)|Portuguesa]] | Two horizontal bands of blue and green separated by a narrow white stripe; the blue band is slightly larger than the green and has a white-edged sun on its upper hoist side. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Sucre State.svg|100px|border]] | 2002–present | [[Sucre State|Sucre]] | Diagonal bisection of white and sky blue, with the state's coat of arms on the upper hoist side and fifteen white stars on the lower fly side. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Táchira.svg|100px|border]] | 1997–present | [[Táchira]] | Horizontal tricolor of yellow, black and red, with two coffee branches under an arc of four white stars. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Trujillo State.svg|100px|border]] | 1994–present | [[Trujillo (state)|Trujillo]] | Two horizontal bands of red and white with a green triangle based on the hoist, charged with a white star bearing a pigeon. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Vargas State.svg|100px|border]] | 1999–present | [[Vargas (state)|Vargas]] | Two horizontal bands of white and blue with proportions of 3:1 on the hoist side; the white field charged with a red-edged yellow sun and the blue with four white stars. To the fly side, four vertical bands of yellow, red, white and blue. Based on the flag of José María España and Manuel Gual. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Yaracuy State.svg|100px|border]] | ?–present | [[Yaracuy]] | A white diagonal band radiating from the lower hoist-side corner. The upper triangle is red, and the lower triangle is blue. On the center of the flag, a yellow sun with a circle showing a green field with brown mountains in the horizon, and a light blue sky with three white clouds. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Zulia State.svg|100px|border]] | 1991–present | [[Zulia]] | Two horizontal bands of blue and black, with a yellow sun in the center charged with a white thunder bolt. Ratio 2:3. |} ===Historical state flags=== {| class="wikitable" |-[[Link title]] ! style="width:110px;"|Flag!!style="width:100px;"|Date!!style="width:250px;"|Use!!style="width:250px;"|Description |- | [[File:Flag of Falcón State (1970-2006).svg|100px|border]] | 1970–2006 | [[Falcón (state)|Falcón]] | Horizontal tricolor of green, yellow, blue with the state's former coat of arms in the center. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Miranda State (1970-2006).svg|100px|border]] | 1970–2006 | [[Miranda State|Miranda]] | Two horizontal bands of blue and green, with a yellow rising sun charged with two cocoa branches in the center. Ratio 2:3. |- | [[File:Flag of Sucre State (1965-2002).svg|100px|border]] | 1965–2002 | [[Sucre State|Sucre]] | Diagonal bisection of white and sky blue, with the state's coat of arms on the upper hoist side and fifteen white stars arranged into two downward-facing triangles on the lower fly side. Ratio 2:3. |- |} ==See also== *[[List of anthems of Venezuela]] *[[Symbols of Venezuela]] ==Reference== {{reflist}} {{National Symbols of Venezuela}} {{Lists of flags}} [[Category:National symbols of Venezuela]] [[Category:Flags of Venezuela]] [[Category:Lists and galleries of flags]] [[Category:Venezuela-related lists|F]]

revision.text:
[[File:Rsg.png|320px|thumb|right]] {{ Location map+ | Germany Rhenish Massif (small) | width=500 | float=right | caption='''Rhenish Massif''' (with elements of neighbouring landscapes):
– Highest points in the sub-ranges and several neighbouring landscapes
– several river/-mouth elevations

City locator 14 2.svg | marksize= 10 | label_size= 75 | lat= 50.87444 | long= 8.02444 | background= #ffffff }} }} This '''list of mountains and hills of the Rhenish Massif''' ({{lang-de|Rheinisches Schiefergebirge}}: "Rhenish Slate Mountains") is a selection of the mountains, hills and foothills of the ranges and landscapes that form the [[Rhenish Massif]] − sorted by [[natural region]]al main unit groups and heights in metres (m) above [[Normalhöhennull|sea level (NHN)]]. :''See also these lists:''

– [[List of mountains and hills of North Rhine-Westphalia|Mountains and hills of North Rhine-Westphalia]]
– [[List of mountains and hills of Rhineland-Palatinate|Mountains and hills of Rhineland-Palatinate]]
– [[List of mountains and hills of the Saarland|Mountains and hills of the Saarland]] An explanation of the abbreviations used is given [[#Abbreviations|below]]. == [[Ardennes]] == The Ardennes lie in Belgium, with foothills in France and Luxembourg. * [[Baraque de Fraiture]] (652 m), Province of Luxembourg (B) * [[Cairn Roy Albert]] (589 m), Province of Luxembourg (B) * [[Hochtumsknopf]] (Hüttensknipp; Waldeck-Frankenberg * [[Uhrenkopf]] (ca. 405 m), county of Waldeck-Frankenberg == [[Süder Uplands]] == The Süder Uplands (''Süderbergland'') comprise ''inter alia'' the historic regions of the [[Sauerland]], [[Upland (Hesse)|Upland]], [[Siegerland]], [[Wittgenstein Land]], [[Bergisches Land]] and parts of the [[Hessian Hinterland]]. === [[Rothaar Mountains]] === The subdivisions of the Rothaar is based largely on historic regions.
