revision.text:
''' World Surfing Reserves''' ('''WSR''') is a program launched in 2009 by the [[non-governmental organization]] Save the Waves Coalition aimed at protecting global surf habitats. The program proactively identifies, designates and enshrines international waves, [[Surfing|surf]] zones and surrounding environments, protecting them from the threat of development.<ref>[http://www.savethewaves.org/world_surfing_reserves Save The Waves Coalition Website, World Surfing Reserves Home Page]</ref><ref name="How Are World Surfing Reserves Created">{{cite web|title=How Are World Surfing Reserves Created?|url=http://thelens.surfstitch.com/2015/12/21/how-are-world-surfing-reserves-created/|website=The Lens|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref>
==Background and mission==
[[File:Huanchaco.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Caballitos de totora]] in [[Huanchaco]] beach sunset]] [[File:HumedalesHuanchaco1.JPG|thumb|250px|right|[[Swamps of Huanchaco]] is an [[ecological]] [[Chimu]] [[Lands inhabited by indigenous peoples|reserve]], about 14 km northwest of the historic center of [[Trujillo, Peru|Trujillo]] city, [[Peru]]. From this ecological reserve the ancient [[Moche (culture)|mochica]] extracted the raw material for the manufacture of the ancient [[Caballitos de totora]] used since the time of the [[Moche (culture)|Moche]] for fishing and [[surfing]].<ref>{{cite web |year= |url = http://www.revistaveadelperu.com/archivo/2005/vea69/articulos/agonia.htm|title=(spanish) Wetlands of Huanchaco|editor = |accessdate =29 May 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |year= |url = http://www.ambiente-ecologico.com/067-02-2000/manuelniquealvarez67.htm|title=(spanish) Wetlands of Huanchaco|editor = |accessdate =29 May 2012}}</ref>]]
The mission of the WSR program is to gain international recognition and support for wave and coastal protection around the world by creating a global network of designated surfing reserves. WSR also recognizes environmental, social, cultural and economic benefits of waves.<ref>[http://www.surfingreserves.org/world-reserves.php National Surfing Reserves, Home Page]</ref>
Leaders in the international surfing, environmental and scientific communities launched WSR at the Value of Waves Roundtable<ref>http://www.savethewaves.org/news/view/56/</ref> held in [[Half Moon Bay, California]]. WSR was created in conjunction with National Surfing Reserves Australia,<ref>http://www.surfingreserves.org/</ref> and has established partnerships with the [[International Surfing Association]] (ISA), and Stanford University's Center for Responsible Travel (CREST).<ref name="responsibletravel.org">http://www.responsibletravel.org/</ref>
World Surfing Reserves is led by an international executive committee and vision council. It is the responsibility of these groups to govern the program and make the final wave selections. For a specific surf site to enter WSR, the region must have exceptional and consistent surf, along with a rich history and culture of surfing, as well as strong community support.
In August 2009, WSR called for nominations from all national surfing federations.<ref>[http://www.savethewaves.org/news/view/93 Save The Waves Coalition, World Surfing Reserves Nominations]</ref> More than 150 sites were nominated from 34 countries. WSR eventually plans to induct 30-40 surf breaks around the world. The program has gained a substantial amount of positive feedback and support from the sport's leaders, including [[Kelly Slater]].<ref>[http://blogs.surfermag.com/industry-news/kelly-slater-joins-world-surfing-reserves-movement/ March 15, 2010, ''Surfer Magazine'', "Kelly Slater Joins WSR Movement"]</ref> You can also read Drew Kampion's ''World Surfing Reserves Manifesto''.<ref>http://www.savethewaves.org/news/view/110/</ref>
==World Surfing Reserves, council and committee== ''Vision Council'': Fernando Aguerre, Will Henry, Jim Moriarty, Tony Butt, Terry Gibson, Len Materman, Miles Walsh, Wallace J. Nichols, Steve Hawk, Wayne “Rabbit” Bartholomew, Tiago Pires, Greg Long, Mark Massara, Chris LaFrankie, Chad Nelsen, Neil Lazarow, Brad Farmer, Manolo Lozano, Juca De Barros, Drew Kampion, Professor Andy Short, Professor Ben Finney.
''Executive Committee'': Professor Andy Short, Brad Farmer, Drew Kampion, Will Henry, Dean LaTourrette.<ref>[http://www.savethewaves.org/world_surfing_reserves/ Save The Waves Coalition Website, World Surfing Reserves Home Page]</ref>
==World Surfing Reserves==
There are currently nine surfing reserves across the world.<ref name="World Surfing Reserves">{{cite web|title=Guarda do Embaú Approved as Next World Surfing Reserve|url=http://www.savethewaves.org/programs/world-surfing-reserves/}}</ref>
===Malibu=== In partnership with National Surfing Reserves Australia, the [[International Surfing Association]] (ISA), and Stanford University’s Center for Responsible Travel (CREST),<ref name="responsibletravel.org"/> Save The Waves Coalition inducted [[Malibu Lagoon State Beach|Malibu Surfrider Beach]] as the first World Surfing Reserve site.<ref>[http://www.savethewaves.org/news/malibu-world-surfing-reserve July 22, 2010, "Malibu World Surfing Reserve" World Surfing Reserves Nomination]</ref> The official enshrinement ceremony took place on October 9, 2010. The date indicated the commencement of the commitment by the local and international communities to protect and preserve Malibu as an iconic surf site.
World Surfing Reserves are nominated through a selection process and there are currently dozens of proposed WSRs covering nearly every continent on the planet.
===Ericeira=== The first World Surfing Reserve in Europe, [[Ericeira]], [[Portugal]] was dedicated on October 14, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ericeira Rides to World Surfing Reserve Fame|url=http://www.worldsurfingreserves.org/ericeira-rides-world-surfing-reserve-fame|website=www.worldsurfingreserves.org|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref> Ericeira stretches 4 km (2.5 miles) and consists of seven separate surf spots, including popular breaks such as Ribeira d’Ilhas and Coxos. Ericeira was recognized for its high density of surf breaks, wave quality, and unique environment.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Portugal’s big waves are boosting the economy|url=http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/181581/how-portugals-big-waves-are-boosting-the-economy|website=inquirer.net|accessdate=31 January 2015}}</ref>
===Manly-Freshwater===
On 10 March 2012, the four kilometre stretch between [[Freshwater Beach]] and [[Shelly Beach (Manly)|Shelly Beach]] was declared the "Manly-Freshwater World Surfing Reserve". The reserve was dedicated in a ceremony on [[Manly Beach]] by world surfing champion [[Kelly Slater]] accompanied by the governor of New South Wales, Australia, Professor [[Marie Bashir]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.worldsurfingreserves.org/surfing-legend-kelly-slater-launches-aus-wsr| title=Kelly Slater Helps Launch Australian WSR| publisher = World Surfing Reserves |accessdate=2012-03-11 | date=2012-03-10}}</ref>
===Santa Cruz=== The World Surfing Reserve dedication for [[Santa Cruz, California]] took place from April 27–28, 2012, and featured a number of events, including a wetsuit fashion show and a paddle out at Pleasure Point. The official ceremony took place out front the Santa Cruz Surfing Museum, where Pat O'Neil from [[O'Neill (brand)|O'Neill wetsuits]] and local officials spoke.<ref>{{cite web|title=Santa Cruz Formally Dedicated|url=http://www.savethewaves.org/news/santa-cruz-formally-dedicated|website=www.savethewaves.org|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
===Huanchaco=== [[File:Surfing en caballito de totora en Huanchaco.jpg|thumb|right|220px|[[Surfing]] in a [[caballito de totora]]]]
Huanchaco beach is a summer vacation spot located in the northern city of [[Trujillo, Peru]]. Huanchaco is famous for several things but particularly for being a surfer's dream spot and its [[caballitos de totora]]. The most famous food here is the [[ceviche]]. Huanchaco is nearby the very famous ruins of [[Chan Chan]]. Throughout 2008 the town underwent significant improvements with all streets being paved with decorative bricks and the main street landscaped with plants.<ref>http://www.munihuanchaco.gob.pe/historia.php Huanchaco history</ref> Huanchaco was approved as a World Surfing Reserve by the organization Save The Waves Coalition in 2012 and officially dedicated on October 26, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |año = |url = http://www.savethewaves.org/news/world-surfing-reserve-in-peru|title = Huanchaco-World Surfing Reserve in Peru|editor = |accessdate =3 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Huanchaco Dedicated as 5th WSR|url=http://www.savethewaves.org/news/huanchaco-dedicated-as-5th-wsr|website=www.savethewaves.org|accessdate=6 February 2015}}</ref>
===Guarda do Embaú=== Now the 9th WSR, Guarda do Embaú is home to a world-class wave that breaks consistently year-round and is known as one of the best surf spots in Brazil.<ref name="World Surfing Reserves"/>
==World Surfing Reserves Google Earth Plug-In== Save the Waves Coalition also created a [[Google Earth]] WSR [[Plug-in (computing)|plug-in]]<ref>http://www.savethewaves.org/news/view/91/</ref> that allows organizations and individuals to view nominated sites around the world. The plug-in allows users to learn about a nominated wave's history, location, environmental characteristics and [[surf culture]]. <ref>[http://www.savethewaves.org/news/view/91 World Surfing Reserves, Google Earth Plug-In]</ref>
==See also== *[[Huanchaco]] *[[Trujillo, Peru|Trujillo]] *[[Malibu Lagoon State Beach]]
==External links== *[http://www.worldsurfingreserves.org/ World Surfing Reserves (WSR)] *[http://www.savethewaves.org/ Save the Waves Coalition home page]
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Organizations established in 2008]] [[Category:Environmental organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Surfing organizations]]
